I put the shell against the metal of a stanchion that had been touched too many times by people learning to wait. The counting inside it smiled and said 4:08 like a prayer and like an accusation. I looked for Valérian because I am very poor at learning what the lesson is until I have paid for it and for the coat it came in.

A moth landed on my wrist, and because I am incapable of respecting the economy of patterns, I fed it a crumb of lamplight that I had hoarded in my hair. It sat with the modesty of messengers who know they will be paid twice for being the sort of animal people forgive. It had no letter for me. That is a letter, too. I went back to the Brèche. The ash-sister did not say anything; she never needs to. The Maîtresse told us we would go to mirrors tomorrow with our eyes closed and that we would learn to open them only when we could say our names without thinking of our faces. Dryden muttered the word hold into his tea until it settled. Estelle measured her hands against the table’s scars and smiled when her palm matched the constellation exactly. The shell on my pillow clicked once like a clock that had decided to be honest for a single minute, and in the tiny quiet after, before the school inhaled for its next trick, I knew that debts had many shapes and that one of them was a freckle that sometimes was a time.Chapter 6

The morning we were given the mirrors, the Brèche behaved as if it had woken from a good dream and was trying not to spoil it by telling us. The stairwell where lessons took their best shape had been hung with frames that did not hold glass so much as they held their breath. We were told to walk with our eyes closed until the word, and the word would come from someone who did not own us. It was not a trick; it was worse and better. It was practice.

“Names first,” the Maîtresse d’Entrée said, and her voice had the grain of a plank that has known the sea and gone on knowing floors after. “Faces after. Faces lie in ways names cannot afford.” Madame Panse stood at the landing with cups of something that smelled like steam warming its hands, and she gave one to anyone whose knees forgot what knees are for. The ash-sister leaned against a pillar that had watched surrender become fashion three times in this building’s history, and she looked at our closed eyes with the affection of a winter window that knows which breath will fog it first.

Estelle went ahead with the bravery of someone who has not yet learned to be suspicious of her own courage. “Estelle,” she said to the breathing frames, and the first mirror stiffened delicately, as if it had been asked to be honest at breakfast. “Again,” said the Maîtresse, soft as thread. “Estelle,” Estelle said, and let the syllables widen until her hands could sit in them. The mirror did not give back a face. It gave her the shape of her name the way water shows you your height by remembering how you fall. Dryden followed, his lashes worrying the air, and when he said his name the mirror handed him a thirst and waited to see whether he would swallow it or let it stand on the rim of the cup and call itself weather.

I did not want to go. I am very good at wanting not to go. But hinges do not get the luxury of sulking; we are built for doors that have no patience with hurt. I stood in front of a frame carved with vines that had never intended to fruit, and I closed my eyes so that if I stumbled I could pretend I had meant to. “Lorette,” I said, and felt the way my names sit in my mouth, like cats who pretend they were not invited. The frame considered whether to pretend it had never met a hinge before. “Again,” the Maîtresse murmured, and I had to decide how not to lie to myself in public. “Lorette,” I said, and let the word crack where it needed to. The mirror breathed. It did not give me a face. It gave me a minute. 4:08, the taste of it on my tongue like iron rinsed three times to be polite. Blue light from an ambulance turning a man’s hand into a flag of meat. A metro mouth that had not decided whether to spit or swallow. Lilacs that had been burned and snatched back from smoke at the last possible second by rain that had been raised to mind its manners.

“Eyes,” said the Maîtresse so quickly that the ash-sister did not have time to smile at my disobedience, and I opened them because I have learned which orders to obey as if I had invented them. The mirror did not hold my face. It held the back of my head, the tilt of my shoulders when I pretended to be taller than grief. It showed me the hinge of me, the place where I turned. Behind that the minute sat and refused to let the glass forget. The emblem on my letter, tucked where it could bruise me when I breathed too deeply, pressed its broken loop into my ribs as if to say you will not get out of this with metaphors.

“Payment,” said the mirror in a voice I would have trusted if it had been a woman asking me to hold her bag while she fastened a child’s coat. “Bring what you cannot leave.” I had brought my left hand, full as always, and my right, which tried to be brave by being easy. The cloth the Maîtresse had given me sat soft as attic air between my fingers, and I held it as a decoy that did not insult the hunter. I could not pay laughter; it had already learned to return to other mouths without me. I could not pay the cats; that coin had rolled into the sea and purchased later. All that left me, once I had told the truth that made me wince, was the thing Valérian called me when I had needed a name he could afford. Mon écho. If I gave that, the mirror would be satisfied and I would have to learn how to want otherwise.

“I will give my echo,” I said, and the ash-sister’s head tilted like a knife that had heard its own nickname. The mirror looked pleased and pitiless; glass prefers exactness. “Left,” said the Maîtresse from behind my shoulder, and I moved the weight into the correct palm so that my right could pretend to be generous without being stupid. I paid. The sound unlatched. It did not leave; it rerouted. I felt it go not out of my mouth but out of my bones, and the loss made a small professional hole in me, the way removing a gear will not stop a clock but will change how it refuses to tell the truth.

The glass warmed in the way of things that are proud of having gotten what they asked for without earning the right to be proud. It softened around the minute like fat around a scar. 4:08 shifted, not away, but deeper into the frame where I could not see it unless I chose to be cruel to myself. “Tuition,” the mirror said, satisfied and administrative, and the letter under my dress cooled as if a tongue had licked its seal for luck. I stepped back and had to hold the railing because the part of me that loved Valérian had never had to be brave about sound before.

Dryden watched me with that opaque offense of boys who suspect someone is better at losing than they are, and Estelle wrapped both her too-big hands around my wrist and squeezed until my attention stopped wandering. “Does it hurt?” she asked, and the kindness of the question was that it gave me a choice I had not had all morning. “Yes,” I said, because I do not believe in confusing children early unless it will make them more elegant later, and I had been asked not to be elegant.

We were fitted with new work as if the day were a body we had to grow into before sunset. M. Chemin showed us a map of the city that had been walked into being by shoes alone, no ink, no paper, the figure-eight laid on its side and then upright and then broken and mended and broken again in the margin. He pointed at a place that was all corners and no center. “There,” he said, and did not say prefecture because he did not want the building to hear its own name and begin rehearsing its smugness. “Numbers pretending to be mercy. You will stand where waiting becomes an art form and you will watch what lines do to the faces that stand in them. If you are offered a ticket, do not eat it, even if it smells like sugar. If you are offered a name, check its weight. If it weighs less than a button, it is counterfeit.”

We went, because the school opened a door that resembled a window that resembled a hole and because students behave like water when the floor tilts toward an edge. The room of surrender that the city uses to pretend it is kind had queues taped to the ground in the geometry of despair. Numbers fed on themselves and called it order. The air tasted like wool coats that had learned how to wait for years at a time. The man in the blue scarf stood three bodies ahead of a woman with a topknot that was trying to be the bravest thing on her head. He was still making bridges with his face. The clerk at the front had fingers like rubber stamps that had never been taught to bring back what they took.

Estelle clutched her packet with the pinch of someone who mistrusts paper in rooms with fluorescent light. Dryden counted the tiles because he could not count the people without being obliged to be kind to them. I slid myself into a seam between two coats and stood where my size made me useful. At the window, a woman with eyelids polished with the boredom of ten thousand days held out her hand for a life. It is the city’s best trick: ask for a life in pieces so small that the donor forgets to make a ceremony. “Minute,” the clerk said, and I tasted the ink in her throat. “Which?” the woman asked, which was better than crying. “Four oh eight,” said the clerk, and scratched the air with her pencil where a freckle would sit if mouths had corners, and I made a sound that would have been an echo if I had not spent it.

The ash-sister appeared at the end of the counter without having had to walk there, which is her idea of telling the truth. “Do not pay with other people’s freckles,” she said, audible to nobody except those of us who already owed her attention. “If the city wants beauty put into numbers, it can go cut its own face.” I hated that she was right. I loved that she was right. The clerk repeated the question because she was paid to. The woman said she did not have a watch, that she did not wear a watch because time made her wrists itch, and the clerk smiled with her teeth the way a drawer smiles when it sticks. The line shuffled and pretended not to practice its cruelty.

I had the letter folded against my skin, the thin white of its seal busy being subtler than blood. I held my left hand and thought of the minute as if it were something I could hide under my tongue and keep from the world until I found the correct amount of wanting to spend. I thought of Valérian’s mouth and its 4:08 freckle, and how he had found a name for me when I was a draft nobody had intended to write that day. “We will pay with if,” Henri had once said to me when a policeman practiced forgetting that the bookstall was not his to arrange. “You can pay with if exactly once and you must not do it in a place that sells tickets.” He had stitched a wallet for my names; I wished now he had stitched one for my conditions. If Valérian had given that minute to me once without knowing, if he had wound himself tight so that I could sleep in a winter where the snow had the weight of loneliness and the taste of sugar that was only salt with better intentions, then I owed him that minute’s safe return. If the Brèche wanted tuition, it could take it from my hinge; there was enough turning left in me to bankrupt a small academy.

The clerk called a number and the speaker made it sound like the kind of poem that keeps its verbs on a leash. The line moved. Estelle squeezed my arm and then let go with an apology because she is learning to be big without being careless. Dryden thought the word hold under his breath until the air decided it had had enough and exhaled him back. “We cannot win here,” he said to the floor. “No,” I said, “but we can steal something we meant to lose.” We left because the kindest thing we could do to the prefecture was to deprive it of our inventory.

Paris held its door to us the way a person holds the door for a stranger they have learned to be suspicious of. I flew low without being a bird, and we found Henri under a sky the exact color of a cheap metal teapot after a long winter. He had a scarf that wanted to be blue and a book that insisted on being poetry even with all its teeth knocked out. “You look like someone who has learned to give up something you loved and cannot think of a way to boast about it,” he said, looking at me and at nobody else, and I put my hand on his counter because I did not want to put it through his chest and hide there like I have wanted to hide inside all my best men. “If,” I said, because I am only generous with words I cannot afford, and he nodded as if he had expected me to spend my once in that shop under that bridge at that hour in that weather.

“I stitched you a receipt the day you left me with your lefts,” he said, and produced from under a stack of novels with lungs the size of postage stamps a strip of glove-leather with my names whittled into it in shorthand a magician might refuse to be caught using. “You will hand it to the thing that pretends to tally and will tell it you have paid with contingency. It will laugh. It will try to charge you interest in nostalgia. You will look at it with the gaze of a hinge contemplating a rusty door in spring. It will reconsider. If it does not, bring me back my own name in a cup and I will drink money out of it until the cup admits it has limits.” He smelled of glue and weather and kindness, which is a hard scent to carry in a city hungry for nouns.

We went to the only clock I knew that enjoyed lying with enough dignity to make the truth blush. The west face at the Orsay took us in as if it had been expecting us, which it had, because time gossips, and this clock in particular has a very untidy tongue for a public instrument. The Maîtresse had taught us the way the third step changes you if you let it; I took that step as if it were a dance with a partner who has already decided to be the better one. Dryden held the idea of breath between his teeth and did not let it fog the glass; Estelle bent her head the way people do when they intend not to be in the way of what is larger than them and would not forgive them for trying. The gears that know midnight better than the word itself hummed the sound of a throat warming before a song, and I told my bones to be brave by being exact.

The woman who had taken me through before was not there. The clock does not send you the same chaperone twice if it can help it; it is its own kind of mercy. I set Henri’s stitched receipt against the lip of the brass where the figure-eight of the mechanism rests before a stroke, and I told the city I had paid with if. The air laughed politely, which is the worst kind of laugh. The emblem at my ribs pricked where the thorn had mended the broken loop and reminded me that politeness is an instrument used to move knives between courses. “Further,” said the minute that had moved into the glass and refused to leave. “Further,” repeated the clock with the pride of a liar who has decided to know his own limits. “Further,” said Estelle, whose hands had learned the length of rope this morning and were practicing on my fear.

I went further. The third step became a fourth, and it behaved like those numbers in my shell that had unlearned arithmetic for a principled reason. My echo was gone and my mouth was quiet enough that I could hear my own hinge turn without being embarrassed by how much I wanted it to sound like a song. The glass did not crack. It reworded itself. The minute opened. 4:08 had a room, and the room had a table, and on the table there was a freckle drawn in ink that had not yet dried. Valérian’s mouth leaned over the table as if deciding whether the freckle belonged to him. The ash-sister sat at the far end, as if summoned by the quality of the light, which had the admirable stupidity of sun filtered through dust in a workshop where love is measured in millimeters and regret in signatures.

“You cannot pay for a minute twice,” she said, and her delight at informing me of this was almost tender. “You can pay for it once and then reimburse it forever. That is what the Brèche sells, little hinge. The habit of repayment.”

“I paid with if,” I said, and laid Henri’s leather on the table with all the ceremony I own. The ash-sister’s eyes softened the way velvet softens light. “Dung,” she said, but she said it like a compliment to the man who had thought to bring muck into the palace to test whether the marble had any respect for what grows. “A receipt is a story about the future told by a liar who intends to be honest later.”

“Later is expensive,” I said, and the minute smiled and spilled a blue light like the wrong kind of nostalgia over my hands. Dryden made a sound and swallowed it before it could find my missing echo and make a mess. Estelle looked at the table as if it were a person pretending to be a door and had failed.

The clock made the shape of a question with its teeth and decided to be generous. “Who caught 4:08 when it fell out of the sky,” it asked, casual as a market woman inquiring whether you prefer pears that bruise easily or pears that hate pleasure. “He did,” I said, and put my hand where Valérian’s mouth had once been, which is a terrible sentence and truer than I will allow myself to feel on days when the work is simpler than love. “He caught it and put it in his freckles and gave it to me with tea in a thimble and told the minutes not to tick loudly when I slept. I will not give you that. I will give you my hinge.” The ash-sister clucked her tongue because she hates melodrama in other people and adores it in herself. “You will not survive without that,” she said, and her voice made the kind of circle that draws chalk around your foot to see whether you will step out. “I will survive sideways,” I said, and took the pin Valérian had given me and pricked my right palm so that my left would not have to do all the work.

Blood is currency that has been pretending to have retired for centuries; the city knows how to spend it better than I do. I pressed my palm to the brass tooth that holds the minute down when it would rather be anything else, and I let the gear chew the idea of me. It did not hurt in a way I can tell you about without lying. It hurt in a way that is most like being told a truth at the wrong time with the right amount of love. The clock swallowed. 4:08 shivered and then sat properly, a good dog briefly. The ash-sister took Henri’s receipt and folded it in her sleeve and did not return it. “Interest,” she said, and smiled like a banker with a sense of humor that had cost her friends.

We came away at the wrong pace. Estelle had tears on her face and refused to be embarrassed. Dryden’s eyelashes had learned a new way to move that would make doors forgive him. My mouth felt strange, as if it had been waiting to be returned to me unharmed since last winter. I reached for an echo I had given and found the space where it used to live. It looked like a chair kept empty for someone who is late as a habit and loved enough to be allowed to be. I put my hand on the glass and said nothing where the word would have gone.

I went to Valérian because I am not subtle about my needs when they involve people who have never asked me to be smaller. The shop was open and irritated at a spring that had learned to be coy. The afternoon had the color of paper that has been handled often by careful hands, and the air along Rue Jacob kept its chin up as if determined to ignore the anecdote of rain building politely in the west. We went to the step as if we had been told to leave our shoes at the door of a house that did not own us, Estelle with her palms open to make a table for whatever answer might fall, Dryden with his lashes counting the streetlights for luck, and me with Henri’s stitched wallet pressed against my heart and the square of cloth the Maîtresse had given me tucked into its own quiet. I crouched until the smell of lichen and footsteps was the only weather my face knew for a breath, and spoke as you speak to a dog that has found its voice and does not trust it yet.

“Do you keep the name we paid for,” I asked, and I did not pretend it was a question that could be wrapped in a ribbon and returned later. I gave it the way I would never again cross Rue Jacob from the left after dusk, the exact path my body made between the café’s awning and the shop with the dyed scarves, the sequence of feet that had preened themselves into habit. We walked on with the aftertaste of being improved by a small surrender. Estelle carried the knowledge in her wrists the way bakers carry recipes, without needing paper, and Dryden hummed a line of song he had been refusing to like and had finally forgiven. They gave us class in a vestibule where plaster had cracked into maps and nobody had decided whether to mend or admire. M. Chemin drew the figure-eight in dust on the floor with his boot and opened its wound with two fingers, tender as a gentleman taking a splinter from a child. “You saw one part hold,” he said, and nodding toward Estelle was as much praise as he allowed; it pleased her hands. “Today you will see what happens when the loop refuses to mend. He did not say prefecture because the word makes buildings preen, but the Brèche made us a door with the sigh of a bureaucrat who had once fallen in love with someone from the theater and had never forgiven himself for being changed by it. We did not stand in the line. We watched it move, the way a doctor watches a throat swallow to see which muscle is lazy, and we learned a great deal about how people make cages and then tell themselves the bars are tasteful. The seam widened where waiting becomes wanting, and wanting becomes rule. I do not know whether most hinges, if asked at a party, would admit that turning is an appetite. Mine is. It wants the door to behave so badly it is almost erotic. He was outside, and his face held itself like a bowl trying to keep from spilling. “You have a promise in your posture,” he said, which is, I admit, the thing I love most in a man, and I threw the promise at his feet and went to the place where people were making a ring that keeps fire from being personal. The door laughed because it had learned to earlier and had not yet learned to stop. “You must drink later,” I told it, my mouth missing its echo so badly that the desperation had to do the work of urgency. Estelle arrived out of the crowd with a palm that remembered ropes and a jaw that had decided to be unbreakable for the hour. Dryden pulled water from his sleeves in the oldest trick and made it forget it was a trick and remember being a weather. We worked until the river decided it was interested and we could step back without being polite about it. The ash-sister leaned on a lamppost and counted in a different language and made a face at me that could have been called grudging respect if there had been cameras and if she had felt like pretending to be sentimental.

Afterward, in the way of cities, a man told a joke that made crying easier. Madame Panse arrived with a pot that had never intended to leave the kitchen and ladled kindness into paper cups that were not ready for it. Valérian stood with his hands in his pockets like a person who refuses to be photographed with his grief. “You broke your line,” he said, and bent as if to pick up a screw, which is his euphemism for consolation. “I broke it yesterday for an orange,” I said, and he laughed and forgave me the stupid poetry of the confession. The shell in my dress counted eight correctly and then giggled about it, which I did not know shells could do.

At the Brèche that night, the door titled The Minute You Would Not Pay sat quietly and radiated the humiliation of a thing that has been resisted correctly. I lay on my shelf with my hands where their lessons could find them in the dark and waited for the building to move. The sea had the patience of a school that knows it will get your children next year if it is dull this term. The city ran its tongue over its teeth and checked for blood and found none and wanted more. The ash-sister came in late and went out later, and she stepped exactly where the boards were weak, not to fall through, but to remind them without cruelty what their job was. I slept under the shell’s counting and woke with the precise headache you get when you have decided to be exact about your promises and the morning has decided to be sloppy. The letter with the white seal lay quiet, which is when I do not trust it.

We were given mirrors again, and I said my name without expecting to hear any old music. The glass offered me a street and a step and a ring and a freckle and a man and a boy and a woman and a door and a hinge, and I chose the hinge because I know who feeds me. In the afternoon the Maîtresse sent us to a corner of the city that does not belong to postcards and asked us to find the thing that wanted to become a school and tell it gently that it did not have the patience. When I bent to listen to the crack in the stone that had begun to lecture a cigarette about responsibility, it said a word that smelled like rust and honey. It said audit. I carried the sound back to the Brèche in my left hand and it made the bones there ring.

“We do not keep ledgers because other institutions do,” the Maîtresse said, wiping chalk from her fingers as if it were sugar. “We keep them because doors like to be paid on time and otherwise they become cruel. You will see auditors. They wear clothes that do not admit to being clothes, and their smiles are made of wax given ambition. You will show them our books with your faces. You will not be elegant. If you can help it, you will be hungry in ways they do not know how to feed.” The ash-sister smiled because she loves a performance where the performers think they are the audience. “I keep accounts,” she said, and I felt the receipt in my pocket warm, which is a sentence I did not expect to think in this life.

Henri sent a boy with a note that pretended to be a bill and turned out to be a poem, and the poem said: Bring back my word if before I forget where it was placed. I smiled and hated him for knowing how to ask me to be careful with something I could only spend once. Valérian adjusted a spring with a sigh he had stolen from the dictionary, and his freckle at 4:08 looked like a minute sitting down after being forced to stand through a ceremony it did not enjoy. Estelle learned a new way to be brave quietly, and Dryden learned to be thirsty without performing thirst. The Brèche shifted in its sleep and opened one eye to watch its auditors rehearse.

On the morning the men and women who like to be math in coats arrived, I put on the habit of being a hinge and left my echo where it could not be asked to be brave and tied my direction into a knot that would hold until lunch. They came with smiles like upholstery and notebooks that smelled of skin that had not forgiven its former owner yet. They asked for our accounts in numbers, and M. Chemin showed them a map written in chalk dust and sighs. They asked for our outcomes, and the Maîtresse brought them a door that had learned where to put its fear and a step that had kept its name and a building that had stopped practicing alarms out of loneliness. Madame Panse fed them stew that tasted like fairness, which is an unflattering flavor, and the ash-sister counted their questions the way a lioness counts the legs of hunters and waits.

When they asked for my work, I did not open The Minute You Would Not Pay. I put my hand on it and paid with direction and held so still that my hunger made a sound like a moth chewing silk. I told them how to teach a door to accept a hand, which is nothing and everything in a city hungry for nouns. I told them about blood and pride and the cost of paying with later and with if. They wrote nothing down; their pens are trained only to notice certain verbs. Perhaps it was enough that they stood there and let the Brèche be a school in front of them without flinching. Perhaps it was comedy. The auditors left with their smiles intact, and we had another day to be the sort of people who know what to do with mornings that reek of possibility.

On the way to my promised line the day after, Paris made the sound it makes when a flock of birds decides simultaneously to forgive a tree for being winter. I was late by intent, which is to say I decided not to be on time and called it a strategy. The shell counted eight and eight and then fell in love with nine, and I tucked it against my skin and let it be wrong in a direction that pleased me. Valérian stood at his bench with his left foot lifted the way bird bones lift when they are happy and pretend not to be, and I put the seven on his counter and told him I had stolen it from the river and he told me it had been stolen from him first and we called that fair. He poured tea that tasted like continuing and not reaching the part where we would have to pretend to part.

I am telling you this because the next thing was a door that bled when I put my hand on it and an ambulance that shoved blue into a minute and a freckle that moved and the ash-sister who said we do what is owed and laughed because she already knew whether I would agree. But I am also telling you this because a hinge is only a hinge when a door decides to be a door, and the city was about to ask me to prove that I had learned how not to turn when turning would be beautiful.Chapter 10

By noon the city had arranged its mouth into that particular tightness it wears before a sentence it suspects it will regret. The light took itself seriously. The Seine rehearsed its reflections like an actress who knows the director loves her worse when she tries. I carried my line like a pilgrim carries a relic, not because I believed in it more than anything else, but because it believed in me exactly as much as was useful. I went to Valérian’s shop first as the string demanded, and found him bent over a watch whose face had decided numbers were immodest. His freckle at 4:08 was where it belongs when a person is in intact conversation with his minutes. We said the small professional kind things that keep catastrophe from smelling weakness. He poured tea as if pressure were a kind of courtesy. I did not stay. The line tugged like a dog that refuses to admire your errands. When I reached the alley off Rue des Quatre-Vents, the door waiting for me had already decided what kind of day it intended to make.

It was one of those Paris doors that has spent a century learning how to be admired. Oak varnished until it no longer remembered forests, ironwork that practiced curlicues every second Wednesday because it refused to get sloppy, brass that had learned to keep fingerprints as gossip, not as stain. The paint along the jamb had been scumbled by a man with opinions about green, and the knocker had a lion that believed its own posture. When I put my palm flat in the place a lung would live if wood hired lungs, it bled. It surprised us both. The red came slow, offended, a small thin sheet that should have belonged to a woman pricking her finger on a needle and finding relief in the drama. The door made a sound that would have been a laugh if it had not been trying to be brave. It knew my kind. It had saved my place.

“You have gotten greedy,” I told it, and my right hand, poor sad thing, mistook the rebuke for a compliment. I took the square of cloth the Maîtresse had given me, the one that smells like apples behind a season we were not invited to, and pressed it to the beam. The cloth took the blood as if it had been taught how not to be squeamish and had overlearned the lesson. It warmed. The door leaned into my palm with the trust of an animal that has been taught a trick it does not quite enjoy. Behind the brass and dazzle, I could hear the sound of an apartment making soup. A woman with a voice like string was telling a boy to leave his shoes where thieves would not admire them. A bird in a cage sang a tune it had borrowed from a falling leaf. The door believed itself necessary. It had decided to eat.

The ash-sister found me by following my politeness. She slid out of a slice of shade and made it her duty to improve it. Her coat refused to be noticed in the wonderful way certain sins do. “It is owed,” she said, as if the syllables were small coins she could toss and retrieve at will. “It has been standing between teeth and tender things for a decade. It will have its mouthful.”

“If I give it blood,” I said, “it will learn to tax suffering. If I give it pride, it will hold out for applause. If I give it a laugh, it will live on candy and shake in the mornings. What would you pay?” She raised her eyebrows with the exasperation of a woman asked to share lipstick she had bought with cruelty. “Later,” she said, and I felt the shelf where Henri had stitched that word into my sleep tilt in sympathy. “Later is a banquet for cowards and kings. Pay with stillness.”

I am not good at stillness. I am built for angles and for the joy doors take in pivot. But the Brèche had been feeding me discipline until it limp-wagged against my ribs like a dog taught tricks against its will. I put both hands on the door, not to open, not to close. I straightened my spine the way the Maîtresse corrects yours with two fingers, and I became architecture. I remembered the first lesson in the stairwell: you are not a net. The door is the net. That day I added: you are a jamb. The hinge can wait.

Behind me, the street reconfigured. Men adjusted their shoulders into valor and women folded their mouths the way you fold a letter you cannot send. Somewhere past the corner where Rue Dauphine pretends to be less beautiful than it is so it does not have to apologize for its prices, a siren practiced its vowels. It was not yet blue, but the idea of blue had already been poured. The shell against my heart counted four and then added a line that was not a number but a place in the mouth where a number will become a word. The door bled again. Its blood had learned the trick of being persuasive.

I held. It is not a glamorous verb. It is not elegant. Holding is what unromantic furniture do when they are best. The ash-sister made a face that was a compliment sewn out of disdain and interest. “If you do it wrong,” she murmured, “you will be splintered and the city will shrug. If you do it right, no one will say thank you.” The door pressed, demanding a story. My left hand, heavy with dead and time edged thin, refused to give it one. My right, scattered, tried to charm and was denied. I did not speak. Without my echo words are labor; I was learning to save them for jobs worthy of wages.

It took a minute, which is to say it took a year and an hour and the precise breath where a bruise chooses its shape. When the door realized I would rather be a wall than a hinge if a hinge meant its kind of hunger, it softened in the way wood does when it stops believing its finish. The bleeding ceased. The cloth cooled. From the other side came the specific clatter of a boy’s shoes being kicked under a chair open-mouthed and too pleased with their plan. The soup went on becoming kindness. The door inhaled and, for once, let the exhale be someone else’s job.

The city rewarded my ugliness with a spectacle, as cities do. Around the corner, where the Rue Saint-André-des-Arts makes a witty mouth of itself, a bicycle offended a taxi and was punished out of proportion. A woman cried out with the sincerity of people who believe surprise makes them innocent. Lungs gathered. The ambulance took its opportunity. Blue shoved its hand into the room and rummaged. The light turned meat into flags. The minute vibrated like a lie taking heart from applause. My shell counted wrong beautifully. I did not turn. Every part of me that was hinge begged. I did not turn.

You do not know what it costs until your bones begin to speak your language. They are old citizens. They remember your first addresses. Mine listed me and found me wanting. The ash-sister leaned with her economy of motion and watched my refusal as if it were art meant for the poor. “Good,” she said, not pleased, and stood very close not because I needed comfort—hinges despise it—but because she wanted me to smell the price she would charge if I failed. On my left, the dead shifted into tolerance. On my right, my names turned their faces to the wall the way cats do when they are embarrassed for you.

When the ambulance had exhausted the block, when the bicycle had been forgiven and folded and the taxi had gone back to practicing its own indifference, when the blue still tasted like broken shutters and men who apologize by telling stories about weather they have given up pretending to control, I let go. The door testily rolled its shoulders and decided to behave. It would demand, soon and again, and I would have to return and remind it that appetite is not a curriculum. But for that hour it drank soup instead of praise. The ash-sister’s mouth relaxed into a shape that might have been called gratitude if it were not being worn by her.

“You will always want to be an instrument,” she said, when we had made a corner that would keep us from pretending the street had not noticed us. “You will want to be used. It is easier than choosing to be. I do not say this as warning. I say this as weather.” She touched my wrist where my echo used to live as if measuring how much more she could charge me before I broke. “When you do not turn in a beautiful minute,” she added, and her voice went softer than my sense of humor allows, “you will be ugly. It will be correct.”

I went on with my line. It was thinner, somehow. Maybe I had rubbed some of the chalk away with my refusal. At the river I did not lean over to be admired by water, which is the most sordid pride. I set my mouth against the idea of blue and made it without a home. I visited Henri in imagination, as if it could count; I did not stop because my promise forbade it and because I did not trust myself to be careful with kindness. Back at the Brèche, the bell that is the shared breath of a hundred thresholds let itself be counted by our ribs. Madame Panse put a cup in my hand with the precise gravity you would reserve for a coin you hope will be falsified into bread. “You smell like a refusal that kept its shape,” she said, and the steam approved of me without asking permission. The Maîtresse did not compliment me, which is her best compliment.

Lessons took the shape of scaffolding that afternoon. We learned to be uprights. M. Chemin chalked a door on air and then wrote a brace inside it and asked us to stand not as door, not as hinge, but as necessity. Estelle managed it immediately, because her hands had been waiting their whole short life to be asked. Dryden attempted ironically and failed and then attempted without irony and failed better. I sweated as if I had been asked to dance in bad shoes at a wedding where the bridegroom had put his heart in the pocket of his other coat. “You prefer turning,” the Maîtresse observed without disdain. “I prefer applause,” I said, because I am not proud in the right ways, and she gave me a look that smelled of knuckles rapped across centuries and nodded.

The letter with the white skin found me that night on my shelf as if it were embarrassed to be seen arriving. The figure-eight unclosed and stitched by a thorn, the pale that is the hungry color. The hand I know wrote one word as if it were trying on a dress it did not care for but which flattered it beyond argument. Pride, it said. Due. The dot where 4:08 would sit if numerals had the right to disapprove lay at the bottom like a seed you do not plant because you are tired of what grows out of you when you try.

Pride is not a currency I keep much of. Vanity, yes. The polite bravery of being seen, certainly. But pride in the clean sense, pride in the rightness of a thing done because it ought to be without expectation of applause or even of convenience, that is not one of my purses. I have borrowed it. I have spent other people’s. I have told myself stories in which I carried it in a pocket, but I am too old to lie to myself in that tone and not be bored. The Brèche demanded my exact change. The ash-sister came to the library of doors with her coat making that sound coats make when they have learned to forgive rain and do not wish to show it off. “Pride,” she said into the wood, which is how you pay a debt and let the building hear you do it. “Can you afford it?”

“I can afford the humiliation of learning it,” I said, which made her smile like a woman who has ordered exactly the dish she wanted to eat and intends her companion to admire the choice. “You will not enjoy the acquisition,” she said, “but at least you will have no leisure for vulgarity. Tomorrow I will take you to a place that will attempt to feed your vanity until you mistake it for pride. If you do not vomit, I will make you write a poem about your cowardice.”

The place was a mirror-shop disguised as an art gallery disguised as a charity. Rue Bonaparte has several. It specialized in frames so sincere you could forgive them their glass. The owner, a man with hair that had decided to be a doctrine and a mouth trained to say words like discourse and community without choking, greeted us at the door with the unctuousness of kindness paid by the hour. Mirrors obey men like that because they are bored. The ash-sister walked through the room as if she were a clean knife moving through a drawer full of filthy spoons. People pivoted on her without knowing they had done it, and their reflections tried to keep up and suffered injuries about the eyes.

We were to stand before a particular glass and be told who we were until our spines learned to choose. The mirror gave me a version of myself with a strip of winter tied around the forehead, the set of a mouth that has been informed and considers itself noble for surviving the news. It offered me a reputation. It would have been useful. It would have opened doors in cities that do not care to pay with hunger. I put my left hand behind my back because I am vain and did not trust it not to offer me a dead whose posture would suit the story. I put my right in my pocket and held Henri’s stitched leather because it pricks if you attempt foolishness. “No,” I said. The mirror tried to bargain. “Less,” I corrected, because that is what pride says when vanity wants a banquet. I looked what I am, which is a woman built like an intention and a hinge built like a woman. The ash-sister’s head tipped into the smallest of acknowledgements. “You will do,” she said, as if hiring a chair.

We took our practice out into the street because if you cannot do it under sky you are pretending for a wall. The city was in one of its moods where it wears coincidence like perfume. Estelle found a man practicing a proposal to the ghost of a fiancé he had misplaced and set his hands where they could not lie. Dryden discovered that a shop window had made a habit of believing itself water and taught it to like the accuracy. I ran into a door that would not forgive me for yesterday.

It was not the same door. It was the kind of door that cousins its grievances. Brass more offended, wood less honest. It had learned to bleed better. It bled at me as a hobby. The ash-sister admired its form. “You could pay with pride here,” she said, knowing the letter in my dress had decided the invoice was past due. “Tell it that it is doing its job and that its job is enough. Tell it to be satisfied with the exact shape of its function. Tell it it need not be dramatic to be essential. Tell it the soup is work.” I hate that kind of speech. It is grandmothers and graves and the good priest a city always keeps in a pocket in case it wants to pretend it did not mean it. I put my hand on the wood. It flinched the way people do when compliments hit a bruise and are therefore accurate. “Sufficient,” I said, and my mouth had to set itself into the sort of line that ruins photographs. “You are sufficient. You do not have to bleed for people to respect how you keep them from the teeth and from the weather. You are allowed not to show us your effort.”

The door hated me immediately. That is how you know the truth has been useful. It tightened its joints and took satisfaction like medicine. The bleeding stopped because I had refused to admire it. The ash-sister made a noise like a man at an opera when the aria chooses not to be beautiful and is therefore the exact sound of a heart that is not lying. “Paid,” she said, and if she had been anyone else, she would have kissed me on the forehead and been punched for it. Pride ticked once under my sternum and complained and then made itself a bed.

I went to Valérian because a hinge that does not get to turn learns to make a door out of a man, and it is not a good habit but it is at least an honest one. He had written a small equation on the air with the tip of a screwdriver and was attempting to see whether watches could understand sentiment expressed in algebra. “They cannot,” he said when I told him I had given a door enough and not more, “but they can be taught to like it when you pretend otherwise.” The freckle at 4:08 was slightly wicked and I did not ask why. He poured tea and we stood close enough that if anyone had walked in without the benefit of living in a city that has learned to be extra polite about love, they would have blushed and bought a clock to apologize for intruding. He showed me a spring that had forgiven a wound by learning to be uglier and being grateful. He called it art. I permitted it the word.

The Brèche took us to the catacombs that night because bones are still the best auditors. They are polite more often than you would expect. They taught me the difference between kneeling and bending. “You bend all the time,” said the lightning-cracked skull in its patient voice. “You call it being good at your work. Kneeling is an accounting. It is when you admit what has leverage over you and allow it.” I do not kneel well. I do not kneel in front of teachers who admire the algebra of their kindness. The ash-sister left us there and went to flirt with a vein of quartz through a wall, which is how she prays. Estelle set her varnished, practised hands on a stack of femurs and asked them their opinion about doors bleeding and I loved her for the question. Dryden said hold to a grave and learned the grave’s idea of later. I told the skulls I had paid pride, and they said only, “Try not to make a habit of it. Pride, like wine, belongs to a particular hour and a particular hunger.”

When we came up, the city had rearranged its furniture. There were men in the street wearing respectability like a glove and a woman with a braid like a consolation prize and a minute that had been leaning against a wall as if it owned the wall. The ambulance, bored, had gone to find someone else’s sorrow. The door on Rue des Quatre-Vents watched me with the dull fascination of a bruised thing that is wondering whether you will bruise it where its friends cannot see. I walked past and was boring for an entire block. I have never been so proud.

The next day the auditors returned with their smiles ironed, and the Brèche went about its business of being judged. We showed them nothing we could pay for with numbers and everything you can only buy with evening. Madame Panse fed them stew that tasted of receipts and told them it was stock and they nodded because you can always sell a man a story if you do it in a bowl. The Maîtresse cut them a slice of our patience and dared them to chew. The ash-sister made a small profit on their boredom. I stood at the back and practiced stillness until my hinge forgot its hunger for half an hour and I nearly wept with how much of me was left when the appetite slept.

At twilight I did a thing that was inconvenient and true. I went to the step on Rue Jacob and laid my cheek on its paint. It smelled of new, which is to say it smelled of lies about exhaustion. “Do you keep the name we paid for,” I asked again, and the step answered with a dignity that almost made me arrogant. “I kept it twice,” it said, and the second time I refused to return it.” It was asking for praise. It had earned a little. “Sufficient,” I said, and it understood it had been loved.

Dryden carried his thirst like a mirror and learned how not to drown in reflections. Estelle held her hands up to the light and permitted them to be called large without flinching. The shell counted wrong with a rhythm that was nearly music and I allowed myself the ugly pleasure of wanting it never to learn the correct tune. The letter with its pale seal lay breathwarm and quiet against my ribs. The figure-eight it wore in its lip tarnished just enough to be less precious and therefore more trustworthy. Pride paid down a portion of the debt that riches seldom admit to owing. I slept the way carpenters sleep the night after deciding to leave a flaw where it can be seen.

The morning brought a small ugliness that looked beautiful as it passed. A woman with a scarf the color of reasons threw herself at the prefecture’s counter and gave away three names in quick succession because she believed that if she outran herself the city would lose interest in her sadness. The clerk with the tidy cruelty asked her for a minute and she offered 4:08 and I went cold all in one piece. Valérian was standing in the square at that moment eating a pear as if pears were a way to take his grief’s blood pressure. The freckle on his mouth turned its face towards mine as if it had its own eyes. I did not turn. Later is very expensive, but so is beauty. I chose the bill I could pay with the coins left in the purse.

We are not always permitted a flourish when we are good. Sometimes the city pretends not to notice a hinge that refuses elegance. I walked my line as if it were a sentence that only makes sense if read with the correct breath. The ash-sister watched from a shadow that had decided to say my name at dawn. She nodded once, the way a woman nods at a student who has done something unspectacularly correct. She will charge me interest for that nod; she keeps accounts of her small mercies. I rehearsed standing still in doorways until the door learned I did not intend to amuse it. I grew stiff and unadmired and indispensable, which is a profession.

That evening the Brèche pulled water through itself like a thread and set us down near the sea again, not because it loves to watch us drown, but because the tide is the best teacher of not turning when turning is all there is. Maître Sel taught us to plant our feet on a wet plank and let a wave find us without giving our weight to it. “You are not a river,” he said. “You are the chin on which it breaks.” Dryden adapted and then forgave himself for doing it badly. Estelle laughed out loud when a wave surrendered its pride and went around her on all fours. I stood stubborn and was ugly and was delighted by my discourtesy.

When I returned to my shelf, the door titled The Minute You Would Not Pay glowed faintly with a pleasure it had not been promised. I did not open it. There are whole kinds of love that are merely skill at choosing not to do something. I pressed my palm to it and whispered the word sufficient as if it were a pet name I was teaching my mouth to like. The shell on my pillow counted eight, stopped, counted nothing, which is its own kind of number, and I slept as if I had been allowed to owe nothing for one breath. In the morning there was a moth on my cheek that had been edited out of several ugly moments and had found in me a paragraph that would permit it to live. It dropped a sliver of paper that had no seal and no emblem and only one phrase written in the hand I will always know. Hold your line, it said. The dot at the end was not a dot. It was a freckle. It sat at 4:08 and made me want to be elegant. I put it under my tongue and kept my mouth closed until want learned, briefly, to be still.

Paris was a city of soot and mirrors, the velvet of dusk stitched with gold stitches where the streetlamps came on one by one along the quays. I lived in the thin places between a window and its reflection. If you pressed your palm to the cold glass of the café at the corner of Rue des Trois-Frères and peered, perhaps you felt a coolness against your lifeline that wasn’t the weather. That was me, Lorette, small enough to sleep inside a spoon, old enough to remember the sound of horse hooves on the cobbles, restless as dust.

I was a fairy, though the word was always too pretty by half. We weren’t petaled and sugar-lit. We were what happens when a story breathes into stone and the stone says yes. On Montmartre roofs, the chimneys were my organ pipes, I played them with the wind. I kept a nest in the broken hand of a statue, and a second home behind the face of a broken clock in a shop that never closed because time there had lost interest. I loved Paris for its layers, because even a fairy knows loneliness and there is a specific comfort in living where people forget their umbrellas and their lovers and their better selves all in one place, and I, a creature with no umbrella and no lover, could collect what fell.

On a Tuesday stiff with drizzle, I had flown as low as a newsboy’s shout when it happened. A moth found me. Not a shy butter-colored moth either, but a night-thick creature like a charred scrap of paper that still remembered the words written on it. It sidled into the air beside me, matched my speed without effort.

“What have you got in your pocket?” I asked, because sometimes when a moth looks that confident, it isn’t here for crumbs of lamplight.

The moth didn’t speak, because they rarely oblige, but it twisted, scraped something against the wet underside of a gutter, and a string fell, and then a coiled thing slid from its body like an unspooling secret. A package hung by threads. I hovered, letting it swing in the drizzle. A wax seal held it: a seal that was neither red nor black but a thin, starved white, so pale it almost counted as a color only out of politeness. The seal bore an emblem that hurt the eye, a figure-eight broken open and mended with a thorn. I sniffed it. It smelled like lilac blossoms set on fire and put out at the last moment by rain.

“To me?” I asked the moth.

It landed on my shoulder and refused to be questioned further.

My fingers aren’t like human ones; my bones have opinions. They can widen and narrow as needed, and I have a trick for slipping through the seams of things. The wax looked brittle, felt like the memory of chalk, and when I pressed my nail against it, a tiny sound came out of it as if a lake had cracked somewhere.

Inside the paper, letters like iron filings had arranged themselves in a hand I recognized from dreams I did not remember having. Lorette à Paris, they began, as if Paris were not the noun but the qualifier.

We are writing to inform you that you have been accepted at L’Académie de la Brèche, School of Thresholds. Term begins at the stroke of midnight on the first night of the new moon, below the west clock of the Musée d’Orsay. Bring what you can carry and what you cannot leave.

It did not say who wrote it. It did not ask me whether I wanted to attend.

The moth closed its wings and became a suggestion.

“Barely polite,” I told it. “Is this a joke?”

I didn’t think so. Rarely has a joke burned that cold when I touched it.

I tucked the letter into the lining of my dress. My dress was made from a handkerchief left at Père Lachaise where nobody cried the night it was dropped. It had a faint scent of iris and old salt when wet. It was wet now. I laughed once, testing the echo of my own amusement against the clouds, and the laugh came back a little late, as if someone else had preferred to keep it. That too had been happening lately.

The moth rose, circled me, and left a line in the air like a filament, like a path a child draws to show where to go.

“Wait,” I called, and the sound fell against the roof tiles and slid off.

I knew the school. Not like people know it, with glossy brochures and proud parents. Our kind didn’t have parents so much as places. But the Brèche was a myth you could misplace and find again. A school built on a crack between what breathes and what merely persists. They say it moves. They say it grows legs once a century and wades into the sea, and there are years when a student opens a door to go to class and steps into a storm and graduates six hours later with kelp in their hair.

The west clock of the Musée d’Orsay. At the stroke of midnight. Bring what I could carry. Bring what I could not leave.

I did not think I had a choice.

I fluttered down toward street level, where the human city had gathered its faces behind glass. The broken clock shop was on Rue Dauphine, narrow and long and smelling of onions from the soup simmering in the back and the petrichor of errant memories. The clockmaker was mostly a clock. He lived in his own work, you see. Time had packed itself into his bones as a joke, and then forgot to unpack. His name was Monsieur Valérian, and he wore threadbare velvet and a small freckle in the shape of 4:08 at the corner of his mouth.

He could not always see me. He could sometimes feel me. He called me Mon écho, and I accepted the name because his voice held no cruelty. I had stayed in his shop for most of a winter when the snow felt like the softest sort of loneliness and being seen would have been the wrong kind. He left out crumbs and a thimble; he told his clocks to tick softly when I fell asleep behind the gears of a carriage clock.

When I pushed the door, the bells shivered, and in three different rooms things chimed the hour, none in agreement. I slid under the shadow of a shelf. We had arranged our languages between us: one part finger-work on lacquered wood, one part tapping the rim of a porcelain cup, one part breath on glass. He was bent over a table, a loupe at his eye. His hair looked like the white fuzz you see on the underside of a dandelion leaf.

“Valérian,” I said. I flew close enough that the hairs on his hand lifted, that he felt me as a draft. He lifted his head. His face opened, the way a house opens when you unlatch a shutter.

“Mon écho,” he murmured. “Where have you been? It’s raining—ghost rain.” He said the last like a joke and then seemed to dislike how it sounded.

I settled on the edge of a tin of screws. They glittered like fish scales.

“An invitation came. A moth delivered it, so I can’t return to sender,” I told him. I tapped the tin once, twice, then slid the letter into the light. Humans could not always read our paper, but Valérian had some Bone in him. Not like a witch, not like a sorcerer. He was a man who had listened too closely to the ticking inside himself and had found the seam. That will do, if you are patient.

He pushed the loupe to his forehead and lifted the letter with hands that had made a thousand small decisions and regretted perhaps three.

“An academy,” he breathed. “I had a cousin who went to the Conservatoire of the Unsaid in Lyon. He died content, and his clocks never lied afterwards.”

“Yes, yes. Clocks terrific. Valérian, would you miss me?” I asked, too lightly, too quickly. I hadn’t meant to.

He put his mouth in a firm line that made his freckle at 4:08 disappear.

“It’s very selfish to miss creatures like you,” he said. “You are a wind. I am a weight. Still.”

“Still,” I echoed.

He poured tea into the thimble. He understood that I didn’t need the tea. The gesture was the point. He looked at the emblem in the seal. “When?”

“Next new moon. Midnight. West clock.”

“That clock is often wrong,” he said, with an irritation he reserved for public timepieces. “It runs ahead when it rains.”

“It always rains,” I said, which was not true, but for us it felt true. He made a noncommittal hum. The steam rose in a column, brushed my knees.

“Be careful with thresholds,” Valérian said. “They always want something in return.”

“I have very little,” I said, and it sounded like a lie, which annoyed me.

“You have names,” he pointed out without looking at me, which meant he was speaking to me directly. “The ones you share and the ones that are afraid to be said. That is enough to pay tuition at most schools. Keep one for yourself. And keep the letter. It smells like a warning.”

On my way down Rue Dauphine, the street stretched. It does that when it wants to be remembered and is afraid it won’t be. I skimmed past a bakery where a child pressed her nose against the glass so hard that the heat made an oval that fogged and bloomed and popped back to clarity; I lined a strip of sugar dust along my forearm because I like how it looks on my skin. I passed a cat who did not see me. This had started recently, the invisibilities. The city and I were forgetting each other in little patches, like moth bites. I told myself that was the season.

At the Pont Neuf a woman leaned over the stone and did not think about the river. The river thought about her anyway. We all do this, mistake our thoughts for a boundary.

“Madame, don’t—” I called, not expecting an answer. She did not look. The rain ticked against her coat like applause. I was angry with the river for its appetite, its foreverness, as if it had invented eternity and now expected payment for the patent. I flung myself in front of the woman's open mouth. Her breath went through me like a needle through silk. It hurt in a way I could not explain. Something old and thin and light stirred in me, like a moth under a glass cloche.

“Madame,” someone said, and it was a man in a blue scarf, not me, tugging her sleeve, smiling too broadly, as if to make a bridge with his face you could walk over. She blinked, stepped back, and the river pretended it had never been hungry. The man widened his hands, and she laughed at how his scarf had gotten wet. They turned away.

I hung there, in the cold. No one saw me. The bridge gave nothing back. I thought of the emblem on the letter, of the cracked loop mended with a thorn. The crack worried me. The mending worried me more.

At sunset I went to see Henri at his bookstall on the Quai de la Tournelle. He wasn’t really Henri; he had three names depending who owed him money. But he had always been kind, and the pages of his books had soft corners. He made space for me beneath a pile of Baudelaire with covers like bruises. When I told him about the invitation he nodded as if I’d said something about the weather.

“You’ll need a wallet,” he said.

“I haven’t had one,” I said. “I carry my coins in my mouth or my hair.”

“Non, a wallet for names. The Brèche will try to steal the ones you aren’t using that day. Spare names to tuck behind other names like a paper between pages.” He cut a square from a glove someone had left, stitched it with coarse thread, and wrote inside it with a pencil dull as a butter knife. He wrote LORETTE in heavy letters and then below that L. Rette and below that L’Orée and on and on until it looked like the way rain writes itself into the river.

“You make this sound like a habit you should have mentioned earlier,” I said.

“I am mentioning it now,” he said, with the small smile of a man who knows he is late and makes a parade about it. “You put the one you use on the outside and tuck the others deep. If you are carried, the deep ones may not wash out. That is the trick. We all live in sausages of tricks; you should know that by now.”

“Thank you,” I said, sincerely enough that he did not make another joke. His fingers smelled like tobacco and glue. He tucked the wallet into a fold in my dress I didn’t know was there. “Tell me about the Brèche,” I demanded. “Not the brochure. The mouth of it.”

He tilted his head, squinted at Notre-Dame where the cranes wore the evening like enormous moths. “It takes children who do not know they are children,” he said, “and it takes old men who aren’t particularly old. It teaches the crossing of places without being torn by either edge. Some students are doors. Some are keys. Some are hands. You—” He looked at me then in that way he almost never did. “You are a hinge, maybe. Hard to love, necessary, creaky when it rains.”

“Charming,” I said, stung. He nodded. He did not apologize. “And the teachers?”

“They will smile and watch your feet. The good ones will warn you when to close your eyes. The bad ones will warn you when to open them.”

“And if I do not go?”

He shrugged. “Then you will stand here some night like this one and feel something pass. It will feel like a train beneath your feet, and you will pretend you are not someone who ever feels trains in the bones, and you will make a joke about weather to a friend who is not that kind of friend, and then you will be angry at yourself for a week with no reason you can mention out loud. I’m a bookseller, mon petit. I live next to a river. I know what it is to see something go and not say wait.”

I had no mother to write to. There was once a tree from which I came, a plane tree in the Square d’Anvers where a boy had carved his initials and forgotten the girl; I remembered her braid. I told the tree. The tree, as trees do, offered shade.

At dusk, I went to the catacombs because sometimes you must speak to bones, even if you are made of stories and stubbornness. It was a narrow place for small voices who wanted to be larger. I did not bring a light. I had my own. It is nothing you would see, a sort of not-shadow that makes shadows behave. The skulls did not mind my presence. They were bored and gave as all bored things do—by asking questions.

“Do you think you will be different when you come back?” one asked.

“I don’t often come back from things,” I said.

“Then you aren’t very good at leaving,” another said liltingly, which was unfair, but bones are honest in unfair ways.

“I’m invited to a school,” I told them. “Where do I put my dead?”

“On the left,” said a skull with a crack along the eyebrow ridge that looked like a lightning strike. “Always on the left. The right hand forgets what it has lost quickly, because we spent so many centuries pretending that was honor. The left hand remembers too much. It will give your dead back when you ask, even if it hurts.”

I put my dead on the left, as instructed. I felt lighter and worse.

On the way out I saw something. It might have been a hallucination. I have those, but they are rarely mine. Something black as a full stop that refused to end a sentence. A shape at the edge of a corridor, a wing that had never touched light and didn't plan to. It was a fairy. Rueful. Elegant the way a knife is elegant. Her eyes were on the catalogues of bones like a librarian who had just realized the shelves could be re-ordered to make night fall at noon.

She looked at me and smiled, small and courteous, as if we were introduced at a dinner party neither of us wanted to attend.

“Are you the ash-sister?” I asked, before I could stop myself. I had heard the name whispered with a sneer by a spider who darned stockings in an attic on Rue Keller. The ash-sister taught fires to pretend to be frost. The ash-sister collected human wishes and fed them back to humans after they’d gone off, in jars with pretty ribbons.

She inclined her head. She had no ash on her; perhaps it was inside. “Names are what people say when they cannot afford to speak to the thing itself,” she said. Her voice was white-noise soft; it seemed to come from the space between my heartbeat and the next. “What is your name?”

“I have too many,” I said, and thought of Henri’s stitched wallet, of its scratchy lines like stitches in a wound.

“Good,” she said, as if I were a student who had answered the first lesson correctly. “You will last longer.”

“Will you hurt them?” I asked, shocking myself with the plainness of it. By them I meant humans. By hurt I meant everything.

Her smile didn’t fade. It changed color somehow. “We do what is necessary,” she said gently.

“There’s another word for necessary,” I said. “We both know it.”

“We do what is owed,” she corrected. “The debt has always been there. They invent names for it, but it does not mind what it is called. It is patient.”

“You’re patient?” I said, and it came out unsteadily.

She lifted one shoulder in a shrug that had cost her nothing. “I prefer to be the verb. It feels better in the mouth.”

“How many will you take?” My wings beat hard against my spine. The air did not move. I couldn’t feel my face at all. When I blinked, the darkness was thick enough to fold.

“You will learn to ask better questions at the Brèche,” she murmured. “If you return. In any case, the number is not the interesting part. The shape is. There is a pattern. We all live inside it. You tug one edge, and the whole city shudders. You will see.”

“See what?”

“How something dies without ending. How something survives without living.”

“You speak like a stupid poem,” I snapped, afraid.

“Then I am in the correct city,” the ash-sister said.

I made a small, involuntary motion, like a flinch. She moved with an economy I envied, vanished into a crease in the darkness you would not see even if you looked for it with a hundred eyes. I stood in the humming, old wet quiet, my fingers on my own ribs, counting. One, two, three. My breath made the faintest frost on my skin. I rubbed it away.

When I climbed back into the night, Paris had washed itself in lamplight. My letter was a square against my heart, colder than it had any right to be.

The days narrowed to a point. I pretended they were broad. I did not say goodbye to many. We are bad at endings, we fairies, because we are too good at beginnings. We prefer to pretend one is the other. I left a piece of myself in every place I knew I would miss: a hair woven into the fringe of a lost scarf at the thrift shop; a thumbprint of light on the brass rail in the Métro; a sigh on the back steps of the Opéra where dancers sat with their stockings rolled down, speaking of their bruises as if they were love letters.

Valérian sharpened his sorrow and handed it to me unlabeled. “You are sure?” he said on the last evening.

“No,” I said. “But I am going.” He nodded as if I had given the correct password. He gave me a pin shaped like a pin, the simplest of charms. “If a door looks like a person, prick them first,” he said. “If they bleed, the door is elsewhere.”

“I won’t be foolish,” I promised, and we both knew I would.

Henri pressed a book the size of a fingernail into my hand, a dictionary of sighs. “Words you can keep. Sighs are lonelier. They get into cracks nobody intends,” he said. “This one is for when your own won’t do."

I made a pile on the edge of the west clock of the Musée d’Orsay. I had come hours too early, and the glass bulged like a watch-crystal, the city a dial. I could see the river unspooling itself, a ribbon with mud on it. Tourists in the museum ate pastries in the café under the clock without looking up; their faces were lanterns in a garden that had never known wind. It is very tiring, that sort of light.

I had brought what I could carry: the thimble, which was a home; the pin, which was a weapon that wouldn’t pretend to be something else; the dictionary; Henri’s wallet of names. I had brought my shame also, rolled small enough to hide behind my left ear because the bones had told me to keep the left hand for memory. I had not brought the feeling I had every morning when I looked down from the roof and thought I could see myself walking along the street below, small and sure, because that feeling hadn’t come back since the letter.

Midnight is a rumor. It is never really a point; it is a neighborhood. The clock stretched toward it, and the rain began again, as if the weather believed itself to be a measure of devotion. If you have waited wisely, you know when a moment is arriving; the air gets a fibrous quality, as if you could tear it and see threads. I stood on the lip of the gargoyle’s mouth, under a slate line of roof, wind at my back. The west clock sang its time with the erroneous pride of public timepieces. A low, second sound answered from within the gears, a note older than bells.

A figure stepped from behind the time. She wore a coat that almost admitted to being a coat and boots that had never been on ground. Her hair was the color of old wheat or old books—things left in the sun. Her face was unpunctuated.

“Lorette,” she said.

“Yes,” I said.

“Good.” She flicked her gaze to the small pile of my belongings. “Those will do. You are also wearing your dead properly. Not everyone listens.”

“I am a hinge,” I blurted, halfway between protest and pride. I wanted to see whether she would smile the way Henri had not. She did not. She looked at me as if I had said the word spoon.

“We will teach you to turn,” she said. “We will teach you not to be broken by it.”

“Are you—” I began, and did not finish. Teacher? Door? Judgement? She lifted one hand, and her eyes were not kind, but they were exact.

“If we name ourselves at the border, the border takes its percentage,” she said. “Walk.”

The glass of the clock should have been cold. It felt not at all. The numbers flipped from gilt to absence. The rain stopped or we stepped between rains. The frame of the clock expanded like a chest drawing breath.

I thought of Valérian’s ankles. Their bones looked like the bones of birds sometimes when he leaned against a stool and I had to leave the room because the urge came strong to hide in his sleeve. I thought of the woman on the bridge and her mouth making questions that the river thought were answers. I thought of the ash-sister standing politely among the anonymous; she is patient, she said. She was a noun; she made herself a verb. I tried to think of nothing, because the letter had smelled like a warning and Henri had warned me about teachers who told you when to open your eyes.

The glass did not break. It slipped. There was only the weight of my thimble and the dictionary and the pin and the names pressing against my ribs, making a bouquet of small pains. I stepped. A second step. The second step was the same as the first. The third was not. The third step was one of those steps that redraw you. I felt it then, a sudden falling, the opposite of flight, a reverse idea of wings. I was not frightened. The feeling was old.

“Do not look for yourself,” the woman said. “You won’t like where you find you.” A cruel thing to say. Perhaps necessary.

I did not look. I tried not to look. The gears turned around us, a patient circle, and the threads of midnight twined and tied, a neat knot, a cheap bow. In the tightness, a memory slanted across me like a shadow thrown by a bird you cannot see; something about the taste of rain from a particular year; something about the sapphired glass of an ambulance; something about a gentleman’s hand, bleeding, inexplicably, by the mouth of a metro.

I shrank inside my skin so quickly that my bones made the sound of a fault line cracking. I smelled lilac and ash. The emblem in the seal of my letter burned against my ribs through fabric, through the paper, through skin, as if it had hands. I gritted my teeth, and on their edge I felt grit.

“Walk,” the woman said again, and I did, because thresholds always wanted something, and perhaps what they wanted was compliance like this, small and vicious and honest.

We came into a place that was not the museum. The world hiccuped. Air resumed around us. I know I was in a room because sound behaved, because light had edges, because I could feel the subtle insistence of a ceiling. The woman took my thimble, set it on a table, left my pin and my book and my names alone, which I admired her for. The thimble looked as humble as ever, but it had never been that small before. Everything had changed another way, again.

“What do I call you?” I asked, because I did not want to think my thoughts out loud where they could trip me.

“Maîtresse d’Entrée,” she said, with a faintness of smile that could have been politeness or disdain, and then she gave me a small square of cloth. It smelled like an attic. “Here. Hold this when they ask you to give something up. It is nothing. It may pass.”

“And if it doesn’t?”

“Then you get to decide what matters,” she said. “It will not be the last time."

Students stirred at the edges of the room. The children Henri had spoken of, who did not know they were children yet. A boy with eyelashes like broom bristles. A girl whose hands were too big for her body. Something that was a girl and a tower at once, with chips of sky in her hair. And others, older in the way one kind is older under another kind of age, faces that had learned to claim their own shadows. They did not look at me long. They were busy with their own thresholds.

I could not help it. I looked down. I had thought my feet would be there. They were, of course—you couldn’t make do otherwise—but they had no weight. They made no sound. When I pressed my heel into the floor, there was the tiniest give and then nothing. I laughed because I did not want to cry. The laugh came back to me on a delay, out of tune, as if someone else had laughed in my throat just before me. The Maîtresse’s eyes flicked, quick as a pin.

“We will give you a bed,” she said.

“I don’t sleep,” I said, automatically.

“Then you will learn how not to sleep among those who do. There is magic in that, too,” she said, and her hand, in a gesture almost gentle, almost not, touched my shoulder and found me solid, or she pretended to. Perhaps she pretended for me. Perhaps for herself.

“Is there someone here called ash-sister?” I asked in a voice fixed to unsmiling.

This time she did smile, briefly, as if the question were a coin she expected and had taught herself to be pleased by. “We do not call her that,” she said. “We call her what she insists she refuses to be, which I will not tell you. It is the only revenge we offer our teachers. Put your book and your names beneath your pillow. Do not sleep facing the window the first night. If you hear the sea, you may be in the wrong building.”

“It moves?” I asked. “The Brèche?”

“It moves, and it is moved,” she said. “We examine the cracks. We do not seal them. There are schools for sealing. You will not be happy there.” Her eyes suggested she knew what she was talking about.

People filed through. Voices rose. Someone cried in a language without vowels. Someone giggled and covered their mouth and then her hands for a moment were not hands. I went where they told me, past a series of doors that are not worth cataloguing because they were not the kind you could find twice.

The bed they gave me was a shelf in a library of doors whose spines had titles like When She Chose the Vase and The Dress Was Gold and The Door You Do Not Open. It suited me. My thimble fit in the corner like a stubborn grief. I placed the dictionary underneath my pillow and the names above my head. I pretended to pull a blanket over me; it was more for their comfort than mine. I inspected my edges the way you look for splinters after doing something stupid, a hammer maybe, a ladder.

Somewhere, someone sang. The song had incorrect words and a perfect tune. It hurt in the way a memory that is not yours hurts when it recognizes you.

I tried not to think about my third step on the clock and how familiar the fall had felt. I tried not to think about the ash-sister saying we do what is owed. I tried not to think of thresholds and their dinners. The Maîtresse had told me to hold the square of cloth when asked to give something up. I held it now as a rehearsal.
