It smelled of dust and apples. It was nothing. It was something.

I closed my eyes because she had told me not to. On my left I kept my dead. On my right, the names. My head floated a little above my pillow, as it sometimes does. I listened to the breathing of those who slept. It is important to admit what to envy. I envied them. Quietly.

Paris stayed outside, but I could hear it, a faint percussion through the bricks, as if the city had become a drum you could hold against your ear, and the river a heartbeat that does not remember to stop, which is lucky for so many. The academy sighed and settled, old timbers talking to old stone. I thought I could still smell lilacs and something burnt.

I counted my breaths not to sleep, but to watch time behave. One, two, three, four. At four I remembered a street crossing with no traffic and a car that did not appear because there was never such a car; at seven I remembered a light turning green and a woman waiting under the awning of a flower shop; at nine I remembered fog. The remembering had peculiar teeth. I let it bite. It was maybe my first lesson.

In the dark a whisper played itself like a closing hand. A voice on the crack of hearing, not the ash-sister’s, not the Maîtresse’s, something with a patience longer than naming. It said: stay on the left. It said: bring what you cannot leave.

I held my breath, a small disobedience. I opened my eyes. I expected my darkness. There was a slant of something like moon. I reached out and my fingers passed through my own shadow. It is nothing, I thought, which is not true. But you can live quite a long time on things that are not true, if the city loves you and you love it back. I folded my hand. I put it on my ribs. I felt the thump. For now. For now, I thought, for now, for now, as if repeating it would make it less of a promise you cannot keep.

In the morning the Brèche pretended to be ordinary, which was one of its best tricks. A bell rang that was not a bell but the shared intake of breath of a hundred doorframes. Light patted the walls like a host making sure the furniture had not moved in the night. I lay on my shelf and listened to wood remember it had been a tree and to stone remember it had been a river and to my own ribs remember they had once not needed names. Sleep had not come, but I had kept it company from nearby; that counts, I am told. When I sat up, the dictionary slid and sighed under my hand with the polite dismay of a book that had not expected to be useful so soon. My names were still there. I checked them with the anxious efficiency of someone who has already lost something once that morning and refuses to say it out loud.

A girl who had slept two doors down blinked at me with the guileless stare of someone who had not yet picked an age and was trying on several. Her hair was the color of worn coins, and her hands were too big in a way that suggested intention rather than error, as if they were practicing for a version of her future where she would hold more than seemed decent. “Are you new?” she asked, and then made a face, because everyone here was new, always, each hallway pretending to be another and winning.

“I am chapter two,” I said, unhelpfully, because that is what the morning felt like. She laughed in the way of a child who has learned that laughter is a form of currency and spends it when she doesn’t want to answer a question. “I’m called Lorette,” I added, because civility keeps you from slipping too quickly, and gave her a name from the outside of Henri’s wallet.

She rolled my name in her mouth as if testing a pebble for smoothness. “They called me Estelle,” she said, with the same sideways emphasis. “I’m practicing. My mother wanted to call me Stone. She had a sense of humor.” She held up one oversized palm, and the lines down it were thick as ropes. The smell of chalk dust and rain came off her, as if she had slept under a staircase.

“We should go where the bell wants,” I said, and we went, because that is also a trick: walking when something calls you without asking how it knows your address.

The refectory pretended to be a kitchen inside a train station that had never had trains, which I liked very much. The tables were long and narrow and had scratches that made constellations if you tipped your head. The food was what you expect from a school that interrogates thresholds: slices of bread with the crusts on and off simultaneously; honey that refused to drip until someone told a truth; tea that tasted like weather. I sipped the weather and felt last night’s rain kiss me again and then pull back in embarrassment. A boy with eyelashes like small broom bristles and a bruise of ink on his thumb swore at his cup under his breath in a language that involved a great deal of air. “If it will not pour, you must name it,” a woman said kindly as she set down a plate that might have contained pears and might have contained the memory of pears. “The tea, not your anger. Anger hates being named before breakfast.” She smiled, and I did not trust her at all because her smile had the seamed precision of upholstery. “I am Madame Panse,” she added. “I will feed you. I will never feed you twice the same thing. You will forgive this or you will not; it will not change my menu.”

There was a lecture in a stairwell because sometimes steps teach you better than chairs. We sat and stood and leaned and pretended the handrail was not a serpent. The Maîtresse d’Entrée looked precisely the way she had the night before, which for once reassured me; change is easier when you can point at what did not. She spoke without raising her voice, and yet her words did not lose their edges in the treads. “You will learn to cross,” she said, as if stating arithmetic. “Not because it is noble, but because it is necessary. I will not flatter you with destiny; we have none to sell. There are other schools where they bind you with prophecy and then charge tuition for the rope. We do work. Sometimes you will like it. Sometimes it will like you. I recommend you not count on either.”

She had us hold out our hands. “Left,” she said, and a few of the children made the wrong choice because children do. Her gaze did not soften; she repeated herself until each left hand sat cupped like an offering. “This is where you keep what you can’t leave. You will find it fills quickly. Do not confuse what you cannot leave with what you ought not take. There are differences. Sometimes they are not big. You will learn to tell them with your eyes closed.”

She passed between us and laid on each palm a weight you could not see. It made my bones ring. Estelle hissed and then hid her hiss behind her teeth as if embarrassed by its sincerity. The boy with the ink bruise swallowed and then swallowed again, and I watched the swallow push down his throat like a coin in a vending machine. When the Maîtresse reached me, her fingers touched the place where my lifeline used to be before it ran away into other people’s stories. The weight she put there recognized me, like a scent you know from a past where you had a different voice. It wasn’t grief, though it knew grief’s shoes. It wasn’t obligation, though it had obligation’s posture. It was perhaps the habit of being a hinge. It sat and waited to be turned.

“In your right,” she said after a heartbeat, “you will keep what can be given.” She smiled then at one of the doors that had chosen to be a door today. “You will run out faster. This is ordinary. Do not dramatize it. You are not starving because you cannot give something up; you are starving because you keep trying to feed your debts caramel.”

She made us walk. Not far. The first lesson was to take a step without carrying the room with you. I found I had always failed at this; I was constantly dragging lint and eye-corners and breath-echoes behind me. “You are not a net,” she said when she saw me watch my own trail, and then relented and added, “You are a hinge. The door is the net.” The word hinge lived in her mouth as if she thought it unromantic, which I appreciated like a glass of water with no flowers in it.

After the stairwell, there was a class in a hallway where each doorknob had a different temperature and several of them had opinions. A man who introduced himself as M. Chemin wrote a figure-eight on the air with a piece of chalk and then opened its middle like a purse. “This is the school’s map,” he said, simply, and that seemed honest. The emblem from my letter flickered in the loop. He pinched the break in the eight very gently. “You do not mend a crack by forgetting it,” he said. “You do not leave it screaming, either. You stitch. You expect tenderness from neither thread nor skin. Those of you who have only ever been threads will find this frustrating. Those of you who have only ever been skin will find it unfair. Good. Fairness is a myth we invented to hide debt.”

He saw how I watched, and he nodded at me as if to say yes, you were invited for a reason you will not like. Estelle’s hand crept into mine with the speed of hail. I did not pull away. “We are going to the city today,” M. Chemin added, casual in the manner of doctors announcing minor surgeries. “Pairs of two and threes. You will find a threshold and you will ask for its name, and when it asks for your price, you will pay with something you did not bring. If you cannot pay, you will borrow carefully. If you cannot borrow carefully, you will return and apologize. There is no shame in apologies, only hunger.”

At the word city my heart did what birds do when a slate roof is lifted in the morning. The Brèche was not not in Paris, but it was a kind of parallel sentence; it had meaning in common with the city but not all its verbs. The thought of the street shook me like a bell. I saw Valérian’s hands on the inside of my eyelids, sorting small screws with the reverence some men reserve for prayers and others for pockets; I smelled the glue on Henri’s fingers, which always made me think of fathers even though I had never had one and had borrowed the idea from a child who had cried at his bookstall one afternoon all spring; I heard the river make its worst argument.

The ash-sister walked through us as if we were smoke and sat in the first row with the poise of a queen who had no kingdom and no need of one. She wore a dress the color of unripe plums and a coat that would not admit to being seen by anyone born. “You will not be subtle,” she said lightly, as if complimenting us. “You are all too new to be elegant. That is fine. Never mistake hiddenness for finesse. Nine out of ten locks prefer a bold key that admits its teeth.” Her gaze fell on me with the polite weight of a boot on a moth. “Hinge,” she said, and made it sound like both a profession and an insult. “Who taught you to keep your laughter on a leash?”

“No one did,” I said before my caution could sit me down. “It learned.”

“Laughter does not learn,” she murmured. “It breeds. Keep it from the right-hand pocket unless you are making change.” She lifted a paper-wrapped packet from a pocket I could not see. “Homework,” she said, and handed us each a scrap of folded something that did not feel like paper. Mine was cool and soft, like skin that had forgotten about bodies. “Return these with a threshold’s true name wrapped inside. If it smells of your own hands when you hand it back, you have failed. If it smells of iron when wet, you have misunderstood the lesson. If it smells of sugar, we will send you to Lyon, where they make sweets of unsaid things and choke on them. If it smells like not-quite-rain, I will know you paid.”

Estelle and I and the boy of eyelashes were sent as a three. He told us his name as if confessing a crime. “I am Dryden,” he said, and offered two letters like a spare key. “Not from here. From the reservoir between here and there. It is worse in summer.” His eyelashes trembled as if on their own schedule. When he held the folded scrap to his mouth it darkened a shade, then paled again, as if practicing.

The Brèche released us into a courtyard that was not on any map and yet found its own way to a street I recognized. We pressed between the second and third ribs of a wrought iron gate, and there was Rue de Lille, minding its own lies. The sky had the hard brightness of a mirror when you do not want to see yourself. People flowed. Cars paused the way cats do when they realize they have been witnessed doing anything earnest. The museum wore its clocks with continental indifference. Paris smelled like rain and cigarettes and the ghost left by someone who had eaten an orange nearby two hours ago and then thought better of winter.

“Where?” Estelle whispered, and I almost laughed because the question was infinite and the city does not like to be narrowed by whispering. “Where is a threshold?” she amended, correcting herself, as all good students do, and Dryden pointed at everything. Doorsteps. The lip of the curb. The edge of a puddle where water pretended to be deeper than it had any right. The border where café light stops because shadows said please. The seam in a wall where plaster had cracked and a spider had signed its name right over the wound.

We tried the café, not because it was easy but because difficulty often sits under striped awnings and pretends to be expensive. The door had a bell with a ring that sounded like the last coin in a pocket. I hovered an inch from its hinges and whispered, “What name do you answer to when nobody is looking?” The door considered. It considered so long that Dryden began to hum, as if to keep time from taking offense. Estelle laid her big hand on the wood, left fingers splayed, right like an apology. The door laughed. It was not unkind, but it was a laugh for a different joke. “You ask like a window,” it said, and the ash-sister would have been pleased by the precision. “Come back when you have learned boredom.” We backed away, chastened and a little grateful. Doors that answer too readily are usually either generous or hungry, and both charge interest.

On Rue Jacob a woman with a braid like a rope of pretenses sat on a step crying in that tidy way of women who do not intend to inconvenience anyone and therefore produce the most inconvenient sadness. Her handbag hurt my eyes. It had cost a promise. The step under her held three centuries of feet and wine and fatigue. It was low and strong and had lichen in the corner like unspoken interruptions. I bent so close my breath fogged the thin strip of shadow where the riser met the tread. “How do you call yourself,” I breathed, “when nobody is looking at you and everybody walks on you for years and then they repaint you and pretend you are new?” The step exhaled. “I am called Not Worth It,” it said, and the bitterness was old and deserved. “But when the house is listening, I am called Come Home.”

Estelle’s eyes widened. Dryden eased his folded scrap open. It looked like a tongue and a blindfold at once. I laid it on the step and held it there with the bare skin of my palm. The step stirred. It asked the question all thresholds know to ask: “What do you pay?” Estelle reached for her pocket. Dryden reached for his own name. I remembered the square of cloth the Maîtresse had given me and felt the slyness move in my wrist. The step would not be cheated. But sometimes you are allowed to confuse it gently.

I held the square, nothing in it, everything of it, and I thought of my laugh that came back wrong and of the smell of lilacs that had almost burned and of the river failing to pretend it wasn’t greedy. I had very little worth paying that wasn’t a lie. So I paid time. A sliver. Not the time I would miss; the time that knits yourself to a place when you let your breath match a stranger’s breath for one beat and then tell yourself you haven’t. It is an unethical coin, and I would not recommend using it. The step shivered. It took it. A cold skittered along my left hand, and my dead moved over to make room for yet another thing I would have to remember.

The folded scrap drank the name. It became damp with it in the way paper gets damp when it knows a secret that does not belong to it. Dryden wrinkled his nose at the smell. Not sugar. Not iron. Something like rain that had changed its mind halfway down. “Enough,” the step said, dignified as a gentleman who has been offered poor tea and accepts it for the sake of conversation. The woman with the braid blew her nose and stood up straighter without knowing why. Her handbag frowned. Estelle stroked the edge of the tread with the side of her thumb, the way you comfort a dog. We left because we could.

We moved like people who had earned something and were suspicious of it. Thresholds find this alluring. They opened themselves all down the street with the casual indecency of cabaret dancers. We pretended not to notice. Dryden sang under his breath a song about water pretending to be patient. We should not have been surprised when we met hunger.

At the corner of Rue des Saints-Pères and a street that preferred not to tell me its name, the world snagged. A revolving door spun too fast and then not fast enough, and a girl flung her palms against its glass and miscounted her own fingers. It was such a small mistake; it is always the small ones. The door peeled her shadow off like tape. She shrieked in the way of a creature being turned into a vocabulary she did not speak. Her mother said the wrong thing and then the right thing in the wrong order. The door grinned. A man inside it thrust forward with a bouquet that had been expensive and now looked like bad news. The ash-sister stepped out from the shadow of a delivery truck, and the streetlight bent, and the river laughed three blocks away because it laughs at anything that moves.

“Don’t,” I said before my thinking could explain to the rest of me that I had no tools. The ash-sister’s head tilted not to me but to the city, like she was listening through the asphalt for a subway that would pass in an hour. “It is owed,” she said softly, not kind, not unkind. Her eyes met mine and held, and I felt the emblem under my dress press its broken loop into my skin as if the thorn would prefer to be a needle.

I threw my square of cloth at her. It was the stupidest possible thing, and I did it because I am a hinge and hinges sometimes snap with grace. She caught it reflexively. Her fingers closed. The cloth behaved, which was to say it pretended to be nothing and then it was. The ash-sister’s mouth made a shape like annoyance and then like approval and then like hunger again. Estelle pushed her hand between the door and the frame and let the door take the dead skin at the side of her thumb as tax. Dryden put his forehead on the glass and called it the wrong name and then the right one and then laughed in the way the ash-sister had warned me not to use, and the door hiccuped and stuttered and then, like all machines with too many eyes on them, decided it wanted to be moderate.

The girl stumbled, sobbing, into her mother’s lap. They both looked at the bouquet as if it had done all of this by itself. The man pressed a lily at the door for luck and left the city’s grief on the glass where someone else would shoulder it later. The ash-sister folded my nothing square and tucked it in her sleeve as if it had always belonged there. “I will return it with interest,” she said, and I believed her, which is the kind of mistake you think is strength.

We collected ourselves. Estelle sucked at the blood on her thumb with just anger. Dryden squeezed his folded scrap and grimaced at the smell, which had gone from almost-rain to the sound of a coin dropped in a fountain after the wish was already spent. We walked until our feet forgave us for trying to be brave. M. Chemin had told us not to be subtle, and we had obeyed, and the city had noticed, which it did not mind. It minds being ignored more than anything. It took our attention and turned it into work, as cities do.

I veered toward Rue Dauphine without telling the others and without telling myself I was disobeying any instruction. The clock shop was open because it didn’t close. It never closed. Time had no manners. The bell on the door made three different sounds. Valérian looked up with a face that let its hope be seen and then pretended it had not. “Mon écho,” he said, and the freckle at 4:08 near his mouth made its case for permanence.

“I brought you nothing,” I said, because sometimes accuracy is clearest when it sounds like a joke. Estelle hung back with the respect of a child who has walked into a chapel by accident and is trying to behave in case God is present and bored. Dryden pretended to read a clock made from a pheasant’s spine.

“You never bring me nothing,” Valérian said, and the sentence had two meanings and both were true. He saw my folded scrap and my names and the thinness of my left hand. “It has started, then,” he added, voice mild, as if discussing the weather, which was precisely the kind of thing he would do to avoid admitting he was frightened on my behalf.

“It smells of a step,” I said, and handed him the homework because my hands were shaking and I did not want to drop obligation on the floor. “It asked for time,” I admitted, and he sighed without opening his mouth because he used his sighs carefully and did not waste them on air that did not deserve them. He poured tea into the thimble he had kept for me. It tasted like re-labeled rain. “You have blood on your thumb,” he told Estelle, who flushed with pride as if she had been publicly praised for competence. “And iron under your tongue,” he told Dryden, who looked offended and then amused, which is better for a boy who has lived near reservoirs.

I did not say I had thrown the cloth at the ash-sister. Valérian looked at me anyway like a clock that has decided to be honest about its minutes. “You threw the wrong thing,” he said gently. “But wrong things sometimes get to the right place.” He put a little screw on the counter and the screw cast a shadow that looked like a bird. “There is a current,” he said to the room, not to me, or to me but at a distance so I could pretend not to hear if I needed to. “The Brèche is not the only school that has rediscovered appetite. Be careful with teachers who cannot distinguish between teaching and feeding. Those are old verbs; they dress alike at night.”

“Do you miss me?” I said; I had not meant to; the question was an itch I scratched in public. He made a face as if someone had poured sugar in his tea and he wanted to be grateful and could not. “I miss you in the way a clock misses being wound,” he said. “It does not want the hand. It does not want the pressure. It wants the purpose and then calls the pressure purpose to be polite. Go do your work. Come back when you can. If the Brèche moves, I will find it by tapping the bones in my ankle that still want to be gears.”

Estelle touched a stack of faces without glass and shivered. Dryden coerced a cuckoo into revealing how it felt about its job. The answer was obscene and scholarly. We left with less than we had brought and more than we intended, which is a sign of success in any errand worth doing.

When we returned to the Brèche, M. Chemin caught our packets not with his hands but with the habit of having been handed things. He sniffed and smiled with one side of his mouth. “Come Home,” he read under his breath, and the words softened him like wetness softens bread. “Good,” he said, and to Dryden he said, “We will fix your habit of paying with iron; you are not a gate,” and to Estelle he said, “Do not be brave with flesh if you can be brave with pride; pride bleeds slower.” He looked at me last and long. “You gave something you did not have to give,” he said. “Do not mistake generosity for payment. You will be poor if you cannot tell the difference.”

The ash-sister stood at his shoulder and did not look at me, which was a performance, and I admired its form. She smelled of lavender that had been warned. “You have my nothing,” I told her, because I knew better and because knowledge had never stopped me. “Keep it until you need to forget something and then give it back and call us even.” She finally deigned to smile directly at me, a flash of teeth that told me nothing and promised less. “Fair,” she said. “And impossible.” She turned away with the economy of someone whose movements are measured by a metronome other people cannot hear.

Evening in the Brèche was when the building scattered itself and then reconvened, like a family that has learned how to part without making it mournful. The library of doors took a deep breath. The refectory adjusted its chairs so that enemies would sit with their backs together and call it compromise. A window practiced fogging and not fogging and chose fog. I lay on my shelf and pretended to sleep because I had been taught the importance of playacting, and because the lesson moved best if you made space for it. From the hallway came the sound of someone reciting multiplication tables and crying as if numbers were the offense they had always secretly suspected, and from somewhere below came the thin, persistent singing of pipes that had learned to be chimneys and had not forgotten their first love.

I held the square the Maîtresse had given me earlier, not the one I had thrown; it still smelled like an attic and a fruit I could not name. I held it and tried to think of what I would refuse to give if asked properly and paid the right compliments. The list was shorter than it should have been. Perhaps that was goodness; perhaps that was poverty. I put my dead on the left and my names on the right and told myself jokes about weather that would be funny to no one in this building. The joke still kept its shape in my mouth. That was a kind of luck.

At some hour that was between the hours the Brèche recognizes, there was a noise that made my knuckles ache. It was not a bell. It was a practice. Students rose wherever they had fallen asleep and made faces at one another to disguise their fear. “Fieldwork,” someone said. “Midnight,” someone else said. “Sea,” another voice said, and I closed my eyes because the Maîtresse had told me to when it came to the sea and because I had disobeyed her once already today and that seemed enough even for me. I did not look. I did not listen. I counted to four. At four I remembered the light from the ambulance that time that wasn’t mine but which I always found in the blue of shutters. At seven I remembered lilacs and ash. At nine I remembered the thin white seal and felt it press between my ribs like a nail you swallow to show off and then regret even before it hurts.

The Brèche moved. It does it with the courtesy of a cat deciding to forgive you for nothing. The timbers told the stone their favorite word and the stone whispered it to the windows and the windows put it in their mouths and passed it on. We slid. The smell of salt arrived through the vents like a rumor that had paid for passage. Estelle’s hand found mine in the dark and stayed there in the brazen way of a child who has not been taught to ask and therefore knows how to take what she needs. Dryden sang under his breath a line about not drowning if nobody learns your name for it. Above us, or below, or inside, a woman laughed, and it was a good laugh, the kind that suggests kindness rather than triumph.

The Maîtresse’s voice spoke from the place where walls meet ceiling and forget whose job it is to bear the weight. “Keep your lefts,” she said. “Use your rights. Do not pay with what you will miss in the morning. If you see yourself, do not say hello. She does not want to meet you, and you will not like her greeting. If you are asked a question and you cannot tell whether it deserves an answer, put a name in your mouth and do not speak it. The shape will hold you.”

I held a name like a lozenge. I chose L’Orée, which is our word for the edge of a forest and also for the place where stories start. It tasted like sap and cheap wine and a kiss under a bridge that did not happen and did not forget to charge my heart for its absence. The building sighed. The sea put its shoulder against our door. The night admired itself in the glass and the glass pretended not to notice. I thought of the step on Rue Jacob and its two names, and I thought of the ash-sister, noun and verb, and I thought of Valérian’s ankles and the way love makes you want to live inside someone’s sleeve and then calls it something else so you can be proud of yourself while you hide.

Morning would come again. It always does, even in schools that keep different clocks. I would learn to turn without breaking. They had promised that and had not promised to be kind. I was built for that sort of oath. On my left, the dead rustled politely, making room for what I would collect and forget to lay down. On my right, my names slept like cats, ignoring me with their faces while pinning my legs with their weight. Paris breathed beyond the walls like a creature that would not admit to being a creature. The river did not apologize for wanting. The school did not apologize for teaching. The ash-sister did not apologize for anything. I slept, finally, and woke twice without realizing it either time, and when I woke a third time there was a shell on my pillow where no one had put a shell, and inside it I could hear someone counting, and the numbers were wrong in a way that made me feel almost safe.

The shell was the size of a thumbnail and shaped like a question that had learned to sleep on its side. When I lifted it, it made the faint crackle of paper that has been folded too long and forgotten in a pocket woven for a smaller coat. Inside, someone counted stubbornly, a string of numbers with their buttons misbuttoned, marching with the brave incompetence of a parade that did not know which end of the street was the start. I held it to my left ear because the left knows what to do with debt, and the numbers made sense in a way that did not correspond to the calendar. Estelle appeared in the doorway and blinked at the sight of me listening to a shell that had no business having found me, and her face smoothed into relief at the strangeness because ordinary mornings are the enemy of places like this. “Does it say your name?” she asked, and I almost lied and said yes just to see what would look back at her out of her own certainty, but the shell’s whisper was not a name; it was a tide. Dryden hovered behind her, eyelashes fretting, and leaned forward until the shell took his breath and made a ledger of it. He shuddered and said, with the outrage of a boy whose reservoirs had been insulted, that the counting was wrong on purpose.

The Maîtresse d’Entrée rang no bell and yet the building obeyed the idea of one, loosening its corners and then pulling them tight. In the stairwell that taught better than chairs, she told us that the Brèche had nosed against water in the night and intended to use what it found. She did not say sea as if it were an invitation; she said it like a boundary that would pretend to be a friend long enough to make you polite. “You will keep your lefts,” she said, and made us hold our hands up until we could tell the difference without peeking, “and you will learn the arithmetic of edges that do not stay where they are put. The shell is a summons, not a souvenir. You will treat it with the respect you reserve for doors that laugh at you.” The ash-sister leaned on a banister two steps above us as if she had grown there, her coat doing its refusal to be witnessed, and she smiled with the thoughtless patience of a knife that assumes bread will continue to present itself. A man with hair the color of salt-spray and a face that had been carved by a chisel that liked to work slowly introduced himself as Maître Sel, and I believed him because his mouth was the mouth of someone who swallowed thirst for a living. He told us that the sea asks for price in currencies we mistake for generosity. “You pay with thirst,” he said pleasantly. “You pay with direction. If you pay with pride, you will walk in circles until your bones forgive you.”

We were given lengths of dried kelp braided with twine that had once tied up packages of undelivered letters, and we were told to wear them like ridiculous necklaces. Madame Panse handed us cups of something that tasted exactly like low tide at noon in a year you did not like, and when several of the children made the faces people make when encountering truth in broth, she clucked and told them that offense is an appetite with better manners. Dryden pressed his palm to the shell and said he could hear a reservoir emptying backward so that the surface remembered what it had never known, and Estelle confessed in a voice large enough to fill her own hands that boats made her nonsensically angry. I tucked the shell behind Henri’s stitched wallet, in the soft of my dress, where the left side could keep watch. It warmed there, and the counting grew fainter, as if the numbers had found a thumb to hold.

The door to the water was a rope ladder and a circle of glass at once, a porthole that had stopped pretending because it had nothing to gain. The Maîtresse’s finger drew a figure-eight in the air and broke it gently, making space, and M. Chemin’s map-that-wasn’t slid its loop over our heads like a collar that fit everyone poorly but well enough. When we stepped through, the floor forgot us for a second, and then stones took an interest. The morning outside the Brèche was not Paris morning; it was a color that cities can only imagine. Grey in the way that remembers blue personally, with salt on it like a rumor someone swore was true. We stood on a wooden pier that had learned to sigh properly, the boards groaning like knees that had carried love around for decades. On one side the school pressed its shoulder against a building that thought it was a boathouse in a town that does not exist, and on the other the sea counted without counting, a long subtraction across a page too big for our sums. The air tasted of iron things that had been asked to be faithful.

“Retrieve a name the tide stole and is tired of carrying,” said the ash-sister, distributing instruction like cards she had already decided would not favor us. “Return a ring that refuses rust and therefore refuses to tell the truth. Speak to the drowned gate that lets boats pretend their choices are their own. If you are offered a song, pay attention to the verse where the singer runs out of breath. That is the price.” She looked at me last and added, almost idly, “Do not be elegant.” It sounded like an insult and a caress, and I hated how much I appreciated the balance of it.

We went with Dryden again because water prefers the familiar and had already put the outline of him in its pocket. Estelle carried the feeling of a dockworker badly hidden under a schoolgirl’s bravery, and I brought my usual collection of reluctances. An older student named Maud came with us as a chaperone nobody wanted; she had hair the color of wet rope and eyes that had been narrowed by having to recognize too many kinds of fog. We walked a seam of stones slick with a language I did not speak. Barnacles made their blunt arguments at our ankles, and ropes slept in heavy coils that dreamed of throats and would deny it in daylight. Above us a gull made a noise that would have been obscene if it had been said in a room. We found footprints on the weathered planks that stepped into water and did not step out and then reappeared three boards later as if someone had been returned from the middle of a sentence. I shivered and felt the shell answer, a little more urgently wrong than before.

To ask the sea to open a door, you must use a word that was not made with hands. The ash-sister says this sort of thing as if she invented it and the sea had taken notes. Dryden put his face to the split between the boards and exhaled, and the water rose to meet his breath with the politeness of a host that intends the party to last until morning. “Price,” it hissed with the sand in its voice, and the word rubbed my ears raw. Estelle offered pride immediately, because she is built like a door and wanted the test, and Maud bared her throat in that way certain women do when they are not demonstrating courage but reminding fear that they have paid rent. I put my hand in my pocket and felt the square of cloth the Maîtresse had given me the first night, and I held it as instructed and thought very loudly about being poor in the correct direction.

The water did not want breath; it had enough. It did not want iron; it could make its own counterfeit. It wanted something that would make the hinge turn easier when we were not looking. It wanted a morning. Not a particular date with a particular egg at a particular café. It wanted the sort of morning that accumulates behind your bones because you have been kind to a stranger and then forgotten the kindness on purpose. I was angry at that. I have so few of those, and they are small and untidy. But anger is salt with bad manners; it dries you without preserving anything. I thought of a day half a city away when I had hovered above Rue du Bac and watched a woman stoop to tie a child’s shoe as if she were learning prayer in a new religion, and I thought of not letting that memory live with me anymore. The sea sniffed the thought and took it straight from my left hand, where my dead made room and were offended on my behalf. The deck quivered under our feet and parted like lips. We went down in a sway that matched the count inside the shell, except for the places where it did not.

The drowned gate lay three ribbed lengths out, where pilings lifted their skirts to show the barnacles and did not blush. It looked like a door to nothing, hanging on its hinge by obstinacy and rumor, and I loved it immediately because it refused function but would never admit it. A ring of metal glowed around one of the posts, unoxidized and smug, a wedding band that had married itself and the idea of being undecayed. I pricked the wood with Valérian’s pin where a hinge would have been if the gate had remembered its profession today. The wood bled, thin and bitter, and the water laughed in that old way that makes people grow superstitions like mold. “Elsewhere,” I said, and Estelle nodded and put her hand on the untruthful ring as if it were a throat she was fond of. Dryden hummed until the metal remembered wanting to be coin, and the ring let go without pride. Maud wrapped it in a square of what looked like waxed cloth and smelled like a promise made in shallow water. “The name,” she reminded, and we pressed our hands against the gate and asked the question doors are always practicing answers for.

It told us one of its names without being coy. The drowned do not always play at riddles; they tire of it faster than the rest of us, and the sea is very tired. “I am Shut Because You Thought You Could Not,” it said, and the words went into my wrist bones and settled there like grit. We slid the ash-sister’s folded packet under the latch where a latch would be, and the word sank into the material like a bruise behaving itself. The packet smelled, when I lifted it to my nose, of a storm deciding it could wait. Dryden’s face softened with the relief of work accomplished, and Estelle’s hands flexed as if they were reading a future written on rope.

Hunger arrived with the politeness it uses when it wants a tip. A child stood on the steps of stone where the pier met the shore, where algae drew a green horizon an inch above our ankles. She had the look of someone who had been told to wait and had been good about it. The sea had made a ring around her as if to keep dogs off. The ash-sister watched from a shadow that women know before they know their own names. I went toward the child because I am not wise and because hinges prefer doors that try to shut while you are walking through them. “Your hands are wrong,” the child said in a mild voice, and I loved her for the accuracy. “I’m owed,” she added, and the water lifted as if it wanted to see who would go to the trouble of arguing.

I have never liked the way the ash-sister says the word owed. It is too clean in her mouth. “Perhaps,” I said to the child, kneeling so my eyes were level with terror’s eyebrows, “but perhaps the bookkeeper took lunch.” It was a weak joke, but weak jokes have a certain magic when used properly; you can slip a small truth under their hem while nobody is watching. The ash-sister came a step closer, and the square I had thrown at her yesterday pulsed faintly like a heartbeat under her sleeve. “Do not borrow where you cannot be found to repay,” she murmured, and I showed her my empty right hand and my very full left and dared her to call me a liar.

The sea asked price without moving its mouth. The shell in my dress stiffened and the counting stumbled on seven and grinned about it. I held the Maîtresse’s nothing-cloth and let it be what it was. I thought of laughter, tethered and too well-trained. I thought of giving that up and felt my edges complain in a pitch only I could hear. I thought of the thing I have that is least useful and most me. Cats have not seen me since the letter arrived. It had begun as insult and become habit. I could give that. You would laugh if you knew how it hurt. I said to the water, which always prefers the particular, that I would not ask a cat to see me again until I had finished a piece of work I did not yet know the size of. The sea made a sound like someone swallowing an oath, and the ring around the child loosened as if embarrassed to have been seen in public doing anything earnest. Estelle lifted her by the armpits in the way of someone who has hauled sacks of flour with love, and Dryden stood between the water and the air at her back in case a noun decided to change its mind. The ash-sister watched us do all this with a face like embroidery that resented the needle. “Deferred,” she said when the child’s mother ran up with a cry that could have stopped clocks if clocks believed in mercy. “That debt does not vanish. You have purchased later. Later is an expensive thing to love.”

The shell thrummed as if approving a line in a song that it did not expect to like. I put it to Estelle’s ear and she flinched and then smiled the slow smile of someone trying on a coat that fits better than the one she was told to love. “Two,” she said, and said it again, and then the number lost its arithmetic and became a shape that matched the span of her hands. Dryden held the shell and went very still in the way of people who do not enjoy gifts. “Hold,” he said, and then coughed, as if the taste of the word on his tongue had changed the water in his mouth. The shell warmed once and then cooled as if it remembered itself too late.

We walked back as if the pier were a sentence we were unwilling to finish. Maud taught us to swear in a dialect of storms that nobody writes down anymore because the paper cannot float after, and she told us that the ring would try to lie about what it had seen, which is the habit of all things that think rust is an insult and not a kind of loyalty. The Brèche took us in without ceremony. M. Chemin collected our packets with the absent competence of a man who has learned to map the parts of speech that refuse to sit through lessons. He sniffed ours and nodded and said “Shut Because You Thought You Could Not” under his breath like a recipe. The ash-sister returned my cloth folded twice into smaller and said nothing about interest, which worried me more than an invoice would have. Her sleeve smelled of smoke and weather.

That evening I went to the library of doors because the smell of kelp had gotten into the seams of my attention and I needed the dry logic of wood to scrape it off. The shelf where I slept had a new inscription in a language I could read if I practiced kindness to it: Later. It was not an invitation. It was an opinion. I ran my knuckle lightly along the grain and heard a sound under my finger like a throat refusing an apology. The figure-eight on the air hovered in a memory I had not had time to make, and the thorn that mended it pricked through as if the emblem on my letter wanted to be sure I had not mistaken it for anything else. I tried to turn, the way a hinge does when nobody is looking at it and it wants to be good, and the door did not. Later, it repeated, and behind the refusal I smelled a house I had not lived in where the windows are always almost open.

The shell had fallen asleep in my pocket and then woken without my permission. I took it out and set it on my pillow next to my dictionary of sighs, and the two looked at each other like elderly neighbors who suspect the other of borrowing sugar and never washing the cup before returning it. Numbers spilled out again, all the wrong shapes, curls where there should be angles, angles where there should be curves, and I put my palm over the shell to make the voice say please. It did not. I thought of Valérian and the small freckle that sat at 4:08 near his mouth and wondered what time his ankle bones claimed for themselves when he stood at his bench and let the weight of him be part of his work. I felt foolish for missing a man who was mostly clocks. The feeling did not diminish because I told it to.

In the middle of the night, the building flexed its shoulders the way it does when it intends to slip past a refusal. A moth knocked once against the underside of the shelf and then was not a moth. Paper slid toward me as if the school had coughed and found a lost cough in its pocket. The seal was that thin white again, the starved color that pretends to be nothing and then shows you the bruise you left when you thought you were gentle. The figure-eight unclosed and stitched shut by a thorn hurt my eyes, and I licked the taste of lilac ash off my lip before it had time to make a claim. The letter smelled like rain that had been asked to wait. Inside, the hand I knew from the dream I couldn’t remember had written my name as if it were a direction. It did not say you have been accepted; that had already been done to me. It said Tuition. It said Due. It said 4:08 in the corner with a dot of ink that freckled like a mouth opening and closing on a word it would not use in polite company. It said Bring what you cannot leave.

The morning pretended it had not heard. Madame Panse served bread that was not both crusted and not crusted but simply bread, and the tea tasted like having nothing to say to a friend you love and deciding to sit anyway. The Maîtresse d’Entrée spoke in the stairwell and did not mention the sea or the letter because the school does not argue with its own weather in public. Estelle held her cup in both hands and made a face when the heat bit her palms and then smiled as if being bitten were the correct thing to have done. Dryden found a coin in his pocket that he had not put there and returned it to the air, which is the only safe way to be honest in a building like this. I folded the letter along its crack where the figure-eight had broken and mended and tucked it against my ribs where the emblem could burn through if it needed to make its point.

At the end of the day, when classes had finished telling us things we already knew in words we had not yet earned, I went somewhere you will not put on a map. The Brèche keeps a room where people go to practice not promising. It is lined with mirrors that will not admit to being mirrors unless you are cruel to them, and the ash-sister likes to stand there and apply imaginary lipstick while telling you the price of watching yourself break and then not fixing it. I do not go there because I do not enjoy certain kinds of truth. I went instead to a hall where the floor forgot to be a floor every third board and remembered what it had been before wood. There is a window there that only looks out when you have done something you regret while telling yourself it was necessary. I held the shell against the glass and asked it if it had room for one more wrong number, and it said yes with the eagerness of a child who has not yet learned what yes costs.

It was later, both the word and the hour, when the city made itself heard through the pipes, the way a mother clears her throat when you misunderstand something she has said since you were small. The counting in the shell stopped at four and then refused to be anything else. I thought of 4:08 receding like a tide that had decided to be punctual for once, and the corners of my bones made that fault-line noise again that I was trying to learn to distinguish from danger. I did not sleep properly. I lay beside the dictionary and the shell and the letter, and I invented many ways to pretend that tuition could be paid with things I had already lost, and I admired my own inventiveness like a thief who marvels at the weight of what is not yet stolen.

In the morning, the ash-sister stood at the end of my shelf as if she were a portrait that refused to be hung where people could see it. “You received a bill,” she said, not a question, and her smile was small and efficient like a blade that does not brag. “I told you we do what is owed,” she added, as if she were tired of being right, which I cannot imagine she ever is. I showed her my left hand and she nodded because it was heavy. I showed her my right and she shrugged because it never is, not for long. “You will be sent to the place in the city where numbers pretend to be mercy,” she said. “Do not mistake the line you stand in for the line you are crossing. Doors love that error, and they will keep it in sugar for you until you are old.”

I went looking for Valérian not with my feet but with the part of me that has learned to travel by absence. The city breathed through the bricks in a rhythm that was not mine but that I could borrow if I was polite. When I pressed my face to the cold in the window between two bald lamplight patches, there was no clockshop where it should have been; there was a smear of afternoon where morning should have held itself and a smell of onion soup that felt like a mistake. I pulled back before the ache behind my eyes could make decisions for me. I told myself he was as permanent as the freckle at the corner of his mouth and that permanence is a silly word in my line of work. I folded my names and tucked one I had not used in years into my cheek the way you keep a coin for emergencies.

In class, M. Chemin drew the figure-eight again and opened its bruise so gently the chalk did not complain. “What happens when you overpay,” he asked the air, and the air, which had been to school before, did not volunteer. “You are changed before you arrive,” he said, and looked at me as if the answer had my face. “You lose the habit of being one thing. Some of you should have never been one thing. This will suit you, until it doesn’t.” Madame Panse delivered pears that were pears and memories of pears, and even I, who do not eat, admired the elegance of the trick and the kindness of her pretending it was not a trick at all.

I did not open the letter a second time because it would have been greedy. I held it like a vow. At four in the afternoon the Brèche’s clocks, all of which disagree out of principle, agreed to arrive at eight for the minute it takes to be exact by accident. Something on my left hand moved to make room. Something on my right scratched and begged for work. I went to the place the ash-sister had not told me to go and found the line that people use when they are told that mercy can be exchanged for paper. It was the prefecture where permits are issued to souls who want to cross the city without losing their heart in neighborhoods where hearts are collected for sport. The line had a smell like winter coats hung too close together. A man in a blue scarf stood near the back and waved at a woman who pretended not to see him in order to see him better. I was a hinge. I made myself the right size and fit into a seam between a woman’s hat and a man’s impatience. I put the shell against the metal of a stanchion that had been touched too many times by people learning to wait. The counting inside it smiled and said 4:08 like a prayer and like an accusation. I looked for Valérian because I am very poor at learning what the lesson is until I have paid for it and for the coat it came in.

A moth landed on my wrist, and because I am incapable of respecting the economy of patterns, I fed it a crumb of lamplight that I had hoarded in my hair. It sat with the modesty of messengers who know they will be paid twice for being the sort of animal people forgive. It had no letter for me. That is a letter, too. I went back to the Brèche. The ash-sister did not say anything; she never needs to. The Maîtresse told us we would go to mirrors tomorrow with our eyes closed and that we would learn to open them only when we could say our names without thinking of our faces. Dryden muttered the word hold into his tea until it settled. Estelle measured her hands against the table’s scars and smiled when her palm matched the constellation exactly. The shell on my pillow clicked once like a clock that had decided to be honest for a single minute, and in the tiny quiet after, before the school inhaled for its next trick, I knew that debts had many shapes and that one of them was a freckle that sometimes was a time.

Chapter 6

The morning we were given the mirrors, the Brèche behaved as if it had woken from a good dream and was trying not to spoil it by telling us. The stairwell where lessons took their best shape had been hung with frames that did not hold glass so much as they held their breath. We were told to walk with our eyes closed until the word, and the word would come from someone who did not own us. It was not a trick; it was worse and better. It was practice.

“Names first,” the Maîtresse d’Entrée said, and her voice had the grain of a plank that has known the sea and gone on knowing floors after. “Faces after. Faces lie in ways names cannot afford.” Madame Panse stood at the landing with cups of something that smelled like steam warming its hands, and she gave one to anyone whose knees forgot what knees are for. The ash-sister leaned against a pillar that had watched surrender become fashion three times in this building’s history, and she looked at our closed eyes with the affection of a winter window that knows which breath will fog it first.

Estelle went ahead with the bravery of someone who has not yet learned to be suspicious of her own courage. “Estelle,” she said to the breathing frames, and the first mirror stiffened delicately, as if it had been asked to be honest at breakfast. “Again,” said the Maîtresse, soft as thread. “Estelle,” Estelle said, and let the syllables widen until her hands could sit in them. The mirror did not give back a face. It gave her the shape of her name the way water shows you your height by remembering how you fall. Dryden followed, his lashes worrying the air, and when he said his name the mirror handed him a thirst and waited to see whether he would swallow it or let it stand on the rim of the cup and call itself weather.

I did not want to go. I am very good at wanting not to go. But hinges do not get the luxury of sulking; we are built for doors that have no patience with hurt. I stood in front of a frame carved with vines that had never intended to fruit, and I closed my eyes so that if I stumbled I could pretend I had meant to. “Lorette,” I said, and felt the way my names sit in my mouth, like cats who pretend they were not invited. The frame considered whether to pretend it had never met a hinge before. “Again,” the Maîtresse murmured, and I had to decide how not to lie to myself in public. “Lorette,” I said, and let the word crack where it needed to. The mirror breathed. It did not give me a face. It gave me a minute. 4:08, the taste of it on my tongue like iron rinsed three times to be polite. Blue light from an ambulance turning a man’s hand into a flag of meat. A metro mouth that had not decided whether to spit or swallow. Lilacs that had been burned and snatched back from smoke at the last possible second by rain that had been raised to mind its manners.

“Eyes,” said the Maîtresse so quickly that the ash-sister did not have time to smile at my disobedience, and I opened them because I have learned which orders to obey as if I had invented them. The mirror did not hold my face. It held the back of my head, the tilt of my shoulders when I pretended to be taller than grief. It showed me the hinge of me, the place where I turned. Behind that the minute sat and refused to let the glass forget. The emblem on my letter, tucked where it could bruise me when I breathed too deeply, pressed its broken loop into my ribs as if to say you will not get out of this with metaphors.

“Payment,” said the mirror in a voice I would have trusted if it had been a woman asking me to hold her bag while she fastened a child’s coat. “Bring what you cannot leave.” I had brought my left hand, full as always, and my right, which tried to be brave by being easy. The cloth the Maîtresse had given me sat soft as attic air between my fingers, and I held it as a decoy that did not insult the hunter. I could not pay laughter; it had already learned to return to other mouths without me. I could not pay the cats; that coin had rolled into the sea and purchased later. All that left me, once I had told the truth that made me wince, was the thing Valérian called me when I had needed a name he could afford. Mon écho. If I gave that, the mirror would be satisfied and I would have to learn how to want otherwise.

“I will give my echo,” I said, and the ash-sister’s head tilted like a knife that had heard its own nickname. The mirror looked pleased and pitiless; glass prefers exactness. “Left,” said the Maîtresse from behind my shoulder, and I moved the weight into the correct palm so that my right could pretend to be generous without being stupid. I paid. The sound unlatched. It did not leave; it rerouted. I felt it go not out of my mouth but out of my bones, and the loss made a small professional hole in me, the way removing a gear will not stop a clock but will change how it refuses to tell the truth.

The glass warmed in the way of things that are proud of having gotten what they asked for without earning the right to be proud. It softened around the minute like fat around a scar. 4:08 shifted, not away, but deeper into the frame where I could not see it unless I chose to be cruel to myself. “Tuition,” the mirror said, satisfied and administrative, and the letter under my dress cooled as if a tongue had licked its seal for luck. I stepped back and had to hold the railing because the part of me that loved Valérian had never had to be brave about sound before.

Dryden watched me with that opaque offense of boys who suspect someone is better at losing than they are, and Estelle wrapped both her too-big hands around my wrist and squeezed until my attention stopped wandering. “Does it hurt?” she asked, and the kindness of the question was that it gave me a choice I had not had all morning. “Yes,” I said, because I do not believe in confusing children early unless it will make them more elegant later, and I had been asked not to be elegant.

We were fitted with new work as if the day were a body we had to grow into before sunset. M. Chemin showed us a map of the city that had been walked into being by shoes alone, no ink, no paper, the figure-eight laid on its side and then upright and then broken and mended and broken again in the margin. He pointed at a place that was all corners and no center. “There,” he said, and did not say prefecture because he did not want the building to hear its own name and begin rehearsing its smugness. “Numbers pretending to be mercy. You will stand where waiting becomes an art form and you will watch what lines do to the faces that stand in them. If you are offered a ticket, do not eat it, even if it smells like sugar. If you are offered a name, check its weight. If it weighs less than a button, it is counterfeit.”

We went, because the school opened a door that resembled a window that resembled a hole and because students behave like water when the floor tilts toward an edge. The room of surrender that the city uses to pretend it is kind had queues taped to the ground in the geometry of despair. Numbers fed on themselves and called it order. The air tasted like wool coats that had learned how to wait for years at a time. The man in the blue scarf stood three bodies ahead of a woman with a topknot that was trying to be the bravest thing on her head. He was still making bridges with his face. The clerk at the front had fingers like rubber stamps that had never been taught to bring back what they took.

Estelle clutched her packet with the pinch of someone who mistrusts paper in rooms with fluorescent light. Dryden counted the tiles because he could not count the people without being obliged to be kind to them. I slid myself into a seam between two coats and stood where my size made me useful. At the window, a woman with eyelids polished with the boredom of ten thousand days held out her hand for a life. It is the city’s best trick: ask for a life in pieces so small that the donor forgets to make a ceremony. “Minute,” the clerk said, and I tasted the ink in her throat. “Which?” the woman asked, which was better than crying. “Four oh eight,” said the clerk, and scratched the air with her pencil where a freckle would sit if mouths had corners, and I made a sound that would have been an echo if I had not spent it.

The ash-sister appeared at the end of the counter without having had to walk there, which is her idea of telling the truth. “Do not pay with other people’s freckles,” she said, audible to nobody except those of us who already owed her attention. “If the city wants beauty put into numbers, it can go cut its own face.” I hated that she was right. I loved that she was right. The clerk repeated the question because she was paid to. The woman said she did not have a watch, that she did not wear a watch because time made her wrists itch, and the clerk smiled with her teeth the way a drawer smiles when it sticks. The line shuffled and pretended not to practice its cruelty.

I had the letter folded against my skin, the thin white of its seal busy being subtler than blood. I held my left hand and thought of the minute as if it were something I could hide under my tongue and keep from the world until I found the correct amount of wanting to spend. I thought of Valérian’s mouth and its 4:08 freckle, and how he had found a name for me when I was a draft nobody had intended to write that day. “We will pay with if,” Henri had once said to me when a policeman practiced forgetting that the bookstall was not his to arrange. “You can pay with if exactly once and you must not do it in a place that sells tickets.” He had stitched a wallet for my names; I wished now he had stitched one for my conditions. If Valérian had given that minute to me once without knowing, if he had wound himself tight so that I could sleep in a winter where the snow had the weight of loneliness and the taste of sugar that was only salt with better intentions, then I owed him that minute’s safe return. If the Brèche wanted tuition, it could take it from my hinge; there was enough turning left in me to bankrupt a small academy.

The clerk called a number and the speaker made it sound like the kind of poem that keeps its verbs on a leash. The line moved. Estelle squeezed my arm and then let go with an apology because she is learning to be big without being careless. Dryden thought the word hold under his breath until the air decided it had had enough and exhaled him back. “We cannot win here,” he said to the floor. “No,” I said, “but we can steal something we meant to lose.” We left because the kindest thing we could do to the prefecture was to deprive it of our inventory.

Paris held its door to us the way a person holds the door for a stranger they have learned to be suspicious of. I flew low without being a bird, and we found Henri under a sky the exact color of a cheap metal teapot after a long winter. He had a scarf that wanted to be blue and a book that insisted on being poetry even with all its teeth knocked out. “You look like someone who has learned to give up something you loved and cannot think of a way to boast about it,” he said, looking at me and at nobody else, and I put my hand on his counter because I did not want to put it through his chest and hide there like I have wanted to hide inside all my best men. “If,” I said, because I am only generous with words I cannot afford, and he nodded as if he had expected me to spend my once in that shop under that bridge at that hour in that weather.

“I stitched you a receipt the day you left me with your lefts,” he said, and produced from under a stack of novels with lungs the size of postage stamps a strip of glove-leather with my names whittled into it in shorthand a magician might refuse to be caught using. “You will hand it to the thing that pretends to tally and will tell it you have paid with contingency. It will laugh. It will try to charge you interest in nostalgia. You will look at it with the gaze of a hinge contemplating a rusty door in spring. It will reconsider. If it does not, bring me back my own name in a cup and I will drink money out of it until the cup admits it has limits.” He smelled of glue and weather and kindness, which is a hard scent to carry in a city hungry for nouns.

We went to the only clock I knew that enjoyed lying with enough dignity to make the truth blush. The west face at the Orsay took us in as if it had been expecting us, which it had, because time gossips, and this clock in particular has a very untidy tongue for a public instrument. The Maîtresse had taught us the way the third step changes you if you let it; I took that step as if it were a dance with a partner who has already decided to be the better one. Dryden held the idea of breath between his teeth and did not let it fog the glass; Estelle bent her head the way people do when they intend not to be in the way of what is larger than them and would not forgive them for trying. The gears that know midnight better than the word itself hummed the sound of a throat warming before a song, and I told my bones to be brave by being exact.

The woman who had taken me through before was not there. The clock does not send you the same chaperone twice if it can help it; it is its own kind of mercy. I set Henri’s stitched receipt against the lip of the brass where the figure-eight of the mechanism rests before a stroke, and I told the city I had paid with if. The air laughed politely, which is the worst kind of laugh. The emblem at my ribs pricked where the thorn had mended the broken loop and reminded me that politeness is an instrument used to move knives between courses. “Further,” said the minute that had moved into the glass and refused to leave. “Further,” repeated the clock with the pride of a liar who has decided to know his own limits. “Further,” said Estelle, whose hands had learned the length of rope this morning and were practicing on my fear.

I went further. The third step became a fourth, and it behaved like those numbers in my shell that had unlearned arithmetic for a principled reason. My echo was gone and my mouth was quiet enough that I could hear my own hinge turn without being embarrassed by how much I wanted it to sound like a song. The glass did not crack. It reworded itself. The minute opened. 4:08 had a room, and the room had a table, and on the table there was a freckle drawn in ink that had not yet dried. Valérian’s mouth leaned over the table as if deciding whether the freckle belonged to him. The ash-sister sat at the far end, as if summoned by the quality of the light, which had the admirable stupidity of sun filtered through dust in a workshop where love is measured in millimeters and regret in signatures.

“You cannot pay for a minute twice,” she said, and her delight at informing me of this was almost tender. “You can pay for it once and then reimburse it forever. That is what the Brèche sells, little hinge. The habit of repayment.”

“I paid with if,” I said, and laid Henri’s leather on the table with all the ceremony I own. The ash-sister’s eyes softened the way velvet softens light. “Dung,” she said, but she said it like a compliment to the man who had thought to bring muck into the palace to test whether the marble had any respect for what grows. “A receipt is a story about the future told by a liar who intends to be honest later.”

“Later is expensive,” I said, and the minute smiled and spilled a blue light like the wrong kind of nostalgia over my hands. Dryden made a sound and swallowed it before it could find my missing echo and make a mess. Estelle looked at the table as if it were a person pretending to be a door and had failed.

The clock made the shape of a question with its teeth and decided to be generous. “Who caught 4:08 when it fell out of the sky,” it asked, casual as a market woman inquiring whether you prefer pears that bruise easily or pears that hate pleasure. “He did,” I said, and put my hand where Valérian’s mouth had once been, which is a terrible sentence and truer than I will allow myself to feel on days when the work is simpler than love. “He caught it and put it in his freckles and gave it to me with tea in a thimble and told the minutes not to tick loudly when I slept. I will not give you that. I will give you my hinge.” The ash-sister clucked her tongue because she hates melodrama in other people and adores it in herself. “You will not survive without that,” she said, and her voice made the kind of circle that draws chalk around your foot to see whether you will step out. “I will survive sideways,” I said, and took the pin Valérian had given me and pricked my right palm so that my left would not have to do all the work.

Blood is currency that has been pretending to have retired for centuries; the city knows how to spend it better than I do. I pressed my palm to the brass tooth that holds the minute down when it would rather be anything else, and I let the gear chew the idea of me. It did not hurt in a way I can tell you about without lying. It hurt in a way that is most like being told a truth at the wrong time with the right amount of love. The clock swallowed. 4:08 shivered and then sat properly, a good dog briefly. The ash-sister took Henri’s receipt and folded it in her sleeve and did not return it. “Interest,” she said, and smiled like a banker with a sense of humor that had cost her friends.

We came away at the wrong pace. Estelle had tears on her face and refused to be embarrassed. Dryden’s eyelashes had learned a new way to move that would make doors forgive him. My mouth felt strange, as if it had been waiting to be returned to me unharmed since last winter. I reached for an echo I had given and found the space where it used to live. It looked like a chair kept empty for someone who is late as a habit and loved enough to be allowed to be. I put my hand on the glass and said nothing where the word would have gone.

I went to Valérian because I am not subtle about my needs when they involve people who have never asked me to be smaller. The shop was open and irritated at a spring that had learned to be coy. He looked up, and the freckle at 4:08 near his mouth grinned at me like a child who had escaped bedtime and expected applause. “Mon—” he began, and stopped as if someone had replaced one of the gears in his head with an honest question. “My wind,” he said instead, and the word did not fit his mouth yet, but it did not cut him to say it. He poured tea without counting. He did not tell his clocks to tick softly; they did it themselves because they had learned something from the way the minute had behaved under my hand. “You look like someone who has not slept in the conventional sense and is proud of the compromise,” he said, and I laughed and did not hear myself from anywhere except the place behind my eyes where laughter lives when you have spent it. I wanted to tell him I had almost paid with his face, and I wanted to tell him I had chosen my hinge instead, and both were the kind of intimacy that should be explained only to wood and paper, never to men with hands.

He touched the back of my knuckle with his forefinger the way a man will touch a mouse through a glass for luck because he does not know the correct prayer. “Do your teachers know what to call you now?” he asked, and there was the smallest sadness on his lower lip like dust on a church where nobody is praying for rain. “They know how not to,” I said, and he laughed not with his mouth but with his cheekbones, which is a trick I am trying to learn. We sat without needing to pretend we had business, which is also a kind of magic that should cost more than it does.

The Brèche did its trick with the sea again that night, and I kept my eyes closed and held the shell against my pulse so that the numbers would have something to count other than their own wrongness. The building traveled like a ship that had learned walking narrowly and intended to show off, and when it settled, my shelf had shifted exactly one finger’s width away from the door titled The Dress Was Gold, and there was a new door beside me called The Minute You Would Not Pay. I did not open it. I am many things, but I am not a fool every day.

The ash-sister visited the library of doors late, when the chairs believe themselves to be better at being trees than at being furniture. She sat on the edge of my shelf with the lack of weight of someone who has spent her appetite somewhere honest and intends to rest until something more expensive requires her. “You paid with blood like a child,” she said, not unkind. “Next time, pay with direction. That is a coin most people refuse to recognize, and you can spend it without leaving a stain.”

“If,” I said, and she sighed like a door deciding to be a window for a season. “You will run out of that,” she warned, and the warning was a gift wrapped in disapproval so I would be sure to open it. “Interest,” I said, and she tapped her sleeve where Henri’s receipt slept and smiled a small smile that would have made a better woman than me forgive her. “I keep accounts,” she said. “It is a vice of mine. And a hobby. And a profession. You will come to me when the school asks you to begin paying in earnest, and you will want to be elegant about it, and I will tell you again not to be. Elegance is a tax you have no need to pay.”

“Do you ever owe?” I asked, and she did not pretend not to hear. “Constantly,” she said. “I owe the sea a different weather than the one I give it. I owe doors the promise that I will not lock them and I lie about it every day. I owe girls their small brutalities and I turn them into poetry because I am vain. That is why I am so patient with debt. It loves me. I am not offended by that.”

When she left, the shell on my pillow counted three and laughed, and then counted eight wrong enough to feel like a kindness. The letter under my dress sat quiet as a wolf who has eaten and intends still to look hungry for sport. I lay on my shelf with my left hand heavy and my right hungry and told the ceiling my best truth, which is that I prefer people who make a room quieter by entering it, and that I am learning to forgive myself for being the kind who makes rooms listen harder. In the morning, the school would teach us how to cross a street without losing the part of yourself that stands at the curb and waits for the person you would have been under a different weather. In the night, I taught myself how to count without needing to hear myself do it, and I missed my echo badly enough to call it a lesson.

We did the mirrors again because the Brèche believes in repetition with malice. The frames breathed at us as if they were embarrassed by how much they loved our failures. Estelle said her name with her eyes open this time and did not flinch when the glass tried to be helpful. Dryden looked at himself and saw water pretending to be kind, which is the water’s oldest lie and also its most charming. I stood where I had stood and watched the place where the minute had left a hole in the world and filled it with something else. The glass gave me a street and a woman with a braid and a step that had been brave for three hundred years and was asking, reasonably, for a day off. “We mend,” said the Maîtresse, and M. Chemin drew his map in the air where a child could reach it without being punished.

I remembered to hold the cloth when they asked again for what I could not leave. I gave nothing that morning, which felt like theft and tasted like prudence. Madame Panse served pears that were just pears and we ate them like saints who had recently discovered hunger. The Brèche went to work counting its doors and feeding its patience. Paris breathed outside, and the river did not apologize for wanting, and the ash-sister sharpened her smile on the banister and looked at me the way a locksmith looks at a door she intends to love into opening.

When I went to see Valérian later, the freckle at 4:08 had moved half a breath. Or I had. He called me his wind and the word warmed the room without embarrassing the tea. I brought him a sigh from the dictionary that had been collected in a theater where two actors had decided to forgive each other the same night as the audience did not, and he placed it under a cracked glass dome and listened to it as if it were a small bird insisting on being a storm. He told me a story about a spring that had refused to coil and had taught him a better way to be stubborn. We said nothing about tuition because sometimes you must be unscholarly on purpose to have anything left of yourself when the bell rings.

The shell counted again that night, and it forgot seven, and I loved it for that lapse as you love a man who never remembers to pay the exact amount for coffee and thereby leaves you with a debt that is a pleasure to owe. I slept like hinges do, half open, ready to admit whatever thought demanded entrance without checking its shoes for mud. I dreamed of a door whose spine read The Minute You Would Not Pay and of my hand on its page, and in the dream I did not open it. The restraint felt like skill. When I woke, the Brèche smelled of rain that had remembered its manners, and Paris had folded itself so that the street where I had given the step a name lay closer than it had been yesterday. We were to go there in the afternoon and ask the threshold if it had kept the name we had paid for, and I could not decide whether I was more afraid it had or that it had not.

Chapter 8

The afternoon had the color of paper that has been handled often by careful hands, and the air along Rue Jacob kept its chin up as if determined to ignore the anecdote of rain building politely in the west. We went to the step as if we had been told to leave our shoes at the door of a house that did not own us, Estelle with her palms open to make a table for whatever answer might fall, Dryden with his lashes counting the streetlights for luck, and me with Henri’s stitched wallet pressed against my heart and the square of cloth the Maîtresse had given me tucked into its own quiet. The tread remembered us in the particular way old thresholds remember kindness when it endangered them, which is to say with suspicion and gratitude in alternating bands.
